DEBATE.TITLE: EXTRADITION BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:EXTRADITION (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Extradition Bill 1987 concurrently with the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

—Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to say that, at the time of the second reading speech when the explanatory memorandum was presented, there was a paragraph in clause 7 that should not have been there. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal function of the Extradition Bill 1987 we are debating today is to consolidate in streamlined format two existing Acts which separately deal with extradition to Commonwealth and foreign countries. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech says that this legislation is the result of an undertaking that he gave to the Parliament in November 1985 to make an exhaustive review of Australia's extradition laws. He, of course, conveniently omits to mention that the Stewart Royal Commission report, released as far back as February 1983, identified a requirement for these laws and our extradition system generally to be improved.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, a common criticism of the current legislation is that it is so disjointed, mainly as a consequence of piecemeal amendments, that it is almost unintelligible to anyone without legal qualifications. Whilst the current Bill, happily, puts an end to this problem, nevertheless it has taken nearly five years for this Government, since the Stewart report was handed down, to take the necessary action. The new Act will apply to matters which already constitute extraditable offences under the existing legislation, regardless of whether the offence occurred before or after the commencement of the new Act. Transitional provisions are contained in the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 to preserve existing extradition proceedings.

I think it would be useful at this point to give a brief outline of the salient features of this legislation, with the emphasis on changes to the current legislation. The Bill introduces several new principals. Clause 5 attempts to clarify for the first time definitional problems arising out of a prohibition on the extradition of persons for political offences. It does so by excluding from that expression crimes recognised in multilateral treaties as being extremely serious; for example, hijacking, safety of aircraft, genocide, torture, the taking of hostages and the protection of internationally protected persons. This provision goes some way towards meeting that problem.

Under clause 15 restrictions are placed on the granting of bail. First, the magistrate is not permitted to remand a person on bail unless there are special circumstances and, second, there is a prohibition on bail shopping-that is, on the making of a fresh bail application to another magistrate where the initial application has been refused. The effect of clause 15 is to create a presumption against the granting of bail. It reflects concern about the number of millionaire drug runners who have absconded in recent years. Apparently, one Austrian gladly gave us his home, and he, of course, could afford to. Mainly, these were foreigners on the run with no permanent ties with Australia. The loss of these criminals has also given rise to concern on the part of some countries about Australia's ability to fulfil its extradition obligations.

Clause 18 carries on the provision introduced in 1985 which makes it possible for a person to consent to surrender rather than go through the rigours of extradition proceedings. Apparently, experience over the last couple of years has been favourable.

Clause 20 builds on the consent concept by allowing the fugitive to consent to be tried for offences for which extradition cannot normally be granted-usually because the sentence is below the minumum required for an extraditable offence. This will enable the person to return and face all outstanding offences for which he or she has been extradited and thereby have the slate wiped clean.

In the future, formal review and appeal measures will be confined to proceedings before the Federal Court of Australia or the Supreme Court of a State or Territory, and thence to the High Court of Australia. Access will be denied to the administrative review mechanisms under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act so as to preclude dual review processes which have become common practice in recent years. However, it should be remembered that applications by way of prerogative writ to the High Court in its original jurisdiction are preserved under the Constitution and are therefore an additional review mechanism.

Clauses 24 and 25 make provision for temporary surrender so as to allow a person serving a sentence in Australia to stand trial in another country on the basis that the person will be returned to Australia after trial to complete his term of imprisonment. If, at the end of his Australian sentence, the other country still seeks the offender, the Attorney-General may consent thereto. In addition, extradition will be prohibited unless the Attorney-General is satisfied that the person will not be subjected to torture. This reflects Australia's accession to the international convention against torture. The long-standing prohibition on extradition for military offences is retained and specifically recognised. The coalition sees merit in all of these initiatives, and therefore supports them.

Another novel and welcome addition to Australia's extradition laws is the facility in clause 45 that will allow Australia to refuse to extradite its nationals where the requesting country adopts a similar approach in relation to its own nationals. In such cases this Bill thus creates jurisdiction in Australia which will allow Australian authorities to put the person on trial for a similar Australian offence and any sentence imposed would be served in this country.

Professor Ivan Shearer from the Faculty of Law of the University of New South Wales, who I think has been an occasional consultant to the Attorney-General's Department and who is an acknowledged international expert on extradition law, regards this provision as `innovative', to use his word. He said-I paraphrase him-`Save for the very limited Crimes Overseas Act, the Australian Parliament has not previously sought to establish jurisdiction over crimes committed by Australian citizens abroad where no connection with Australia is otherwise established'. Professor Shearer, of course, was writing prior to the introduction of the War Crimes Amendment Bill which is now before the Parliament. That Bill envisages the trial in Australia of persons who committed war crimes during World War II in overseas countries and who now reside in this country and have acquired Australian citizenship or permanent resident status. Professor Shearer went on to say:

The reason for this is that countries of the common law tradition, inherited from England, base criminal jurisdiction primarily on a territorial connection; this basis was historically determined by the feudal, and later the Royal, foundations of criminal justice and by the advent of the jury system, the justification for which was that a person should be presented and tried only by his or her peers, i.e. neighbours who reflected both local knowledge and the conscience of the community whose peace was affected. Countries of the civil law tradition, by contrast, descending from Roman law, see criminal jurisdiction in essentially personal, not terri- torial, terms: it was one's allegiance to, and right of protection by, the ruler that gave that ruler the power to punish a citizen for crime wherever committed.

This explains not only why civil law countries (we are speaking here of the whole of Europe and Latin America, and parts of Africa and Asia) can prosecute their citizens in their home states for crimes committed in Australia, but also why there is a settled tradition in civil law countries (in some enshrined in their constitutions or basic laws) that they will not surrender a citizen for trial in a foreign country. There is no such principle in English law or in countries such as Australia whose laws are based on that tradition.

This fundamental difference in the basis of criminal jurisdiction between the two major legal traditions of the world has presented a continuing problem in the negotiation of extradition treaties by the United Kingdom (applying to Australia up to 1939) and later by Australia. . .

I quote all that because I think it picks up one of the central principles. As Professor Shearer points out, the concept of trying nationals in lieu of extradition reflects the approach adopted in civil law countries. However, the Bill contains an element of retrospectivity in that while extending Australian jurisdiction to cover crimes committed overseas, it applies to crimes that occurred prior to the commencement of the legislation. Nonetheless, this drawback, if it is such, is clearly offset by the obvious benefit for Australian citizens. I am not aware of any principle or policy objections to retrospective provisions which provide benefits. That aspect, therefore, raises no difficulties. The argument in favour of the proposal is twofold: firstly, it removes any possible concern about whether an Australian would receive justice in a foreign land, and it gives weight to those concerns and, secondly, in the event of conviction, family ties and support are maintained. It thus has a sort of humanitarian aspect to it which gives general support to the concept. It should be noted that the power to order trial in Australia is discretionary and arises only after an extradition case has been made out. It therefore provides a useful alternative to extradition.

Before departing from clause 44 there are two other matters which I wish to raise briefly. One is that Professor Shearer has formed the view that the Bill will allow prosecutions in Australia only when, as a result of the person sought being an Australian citizen, the Attorney-General refuses an extradition request using his discretionary powers. He says that under some treaties a person could, under this Bill, commit an offence in one of those countries, return to Australia and not be subject to extradition and not be triable under proposed section 45. It is a nice interpretation point, using the proper definition of the word nice, and I suggest that the Attorney-General's Department could usefully look at this issue to see whether there is a loophole that requires closing. I look forward to what the Attorney-General will say about that in his summation of the second reading debate.

The second matter is one of more practical consideration. This is a new initiative. It is something that has not been done before in Australia. There will obviously be procedural and cost implications, and it will be important, particularly in the first one or two cases, that those who are responsible for the prosecutions do their homework very thoroughly. I am sure that that will obviate any possibilities of difficulties.

The Bill, in part III, makes special simplified arrangements governing relations with New Zealand. In essence, it continues the backing of warrants procedure, which is the basis of existing extradition arrangements between Australia and New Zealand, and among Australian States under other legislation. These arrangements reflect the long and close association between our two countries and our mutual respect for each other's legal systems. Clause 50 specifically spells out for the first time that a solicitor-client relationship exists between Australian officers and officers of the requesting country in relation to communications about relevant proceedings. This will remove an area of doubt and contention and, I understand, particularly in regard to freedom of information implications.

I turn now to aspects of the Bill about which the coalition has concern, and in respect of which I foreshadow that we shall be proposing amendments in the committee stage. The first relates to evidence to establish the extradition case. Clause 19 provides that a request for extradition need be supported only by specified documents. Normally, the documentation would consist of a duly authenticated warrant and authenticated statements specifying the alleged offence and penalty as well as the alleged conduct constituting the offence. However, in some cases, mainly Commonwealth countries, there is an additional treaty obligation requiring that a prima facie case be established as to the commission of the alleged offence. The prima facie test is the rule applied by lower courts in common law countries as to whether the prosecution has adduced sufficient evidence to warrant the accused being put on trial before a jury.

This, in effect, means that we have different standards for determining whether to surrender fugitives depending on whether the request is received from a common law or civil law country. This is, quite frankly, most undesirable. The emphasis is all wrong. Under the Bill, as it is presently worded, we impose a higher standard of proof on requests for extradition from Commonwealth countries with common law systems in which we are more likely to have confidence than we do on civil law countries, whose legal systems are in many cases difficult to comprehend and in all cases substantially different from our own. To put it another way, the Bill places a premium on civil law countries and penalises common law countries. Quite frankly, this is not the way to go.

The procedure whereby the liability for extradition is decided on the papers in effect repeats existing procedures which were first introduced in 1985, at a time-the Trimbole case is an example-when there was a genuine public concern, quite properly, about the need to tighten and toughen up our extradition arrangements. Prior to 1985, there was a requirement for all requesting countries to establish a prima facie case. However, the difficulties of civil law countries in meeting this test, which is foreign to their own legal systems, led to the introduction of the new documentary processes. The coalition's decision to support the 1985 Act, which included the proposal to abolish the prima facie rule for non-Commonwealth countries, was taken at short notice. The Bill for the Act was rushed through the House and we had only a few days to debate it, which is too common an occurrence. The fact is that the prima facie rule has been part of our extradition law since 1843. In view of that, we believe that it should be re-enshrined by this Bill. Let me take some support from what Professor Shearer has said. He stated:

The better solution is to retain the prima facie case requirement for all extradition and to make provision for dispensation from certain technical rules of evidence that presently complicate the proceedings from the point of view of the civil law countries.
In other words, that is the answer to what I know the Attorney-General is going to say to us. Professor Shearer goes on to say:
Canada is presently considering such changes to its laws, having rejected the solution proposed in the present Bill to abolish the prima facie case requirement altogether. We should do the same.

I think that is very good advice. We believe that it is advice that this Parliament should take up. The amendment which we will introduce will reapply the prima facie test as a general rule but will set out special procedures to make it possible for civil law countries to meet that test. In regard to the provision of a copy of the supporting documentation, I want to say that by custom copies of supporting documents are provided to the person whose return is sought in advance of the actual extradition hearing. We believe that as a matter of natural justice there should be a statutory requirement to provide this documentation. We are hoping that there will be an amendment to that end, whether it is from this side or from the other side of the House. Another point raised by Professor Shearer relates to review material. He says:

Clause 21(6)(d) requires higher courts reviewing a magistrate's extradition determination to `have regard only to the material that was before the magistrate.' This would prevent a court from considering new material, such as possibly evidence of political considerations. There seems no reason for such a restriction. The paragraph should be amended to add the words `unless the court otherwise orders'.
The Opposition agrees with this suggestion. It is one of the amendments that will be moved at the committee stage.

At this point I want to raise several provisions which the coalition will not be seeking to amend but which we believe are still worthy of consideration by this Parliament. The specific prohibition on adducing evidence of innocence was introduced in 1985. It is arguable that such a prohibition already existed at common law. In any event, the prohibition is in keeping with the common law principle that extraditions are not trials to determine innocence or guilt. This principle has been cited with authority in a number of British, Canadian and United States cases. To do otherwise would defeat the whole purpose of extradition arrangements, which is to facilitate the return of accused persons so that they can be tried in the country where the offence was committed. Australia has a firm policy not to enter into extradition arrangements with countries which do not have a judicial system that can justly try the issues. Regulations to give effect to extradition arrangements are, of course, disallowable by the Senate.

The issue has surfaced recently in Australia in the Orionia case in which two persons are attempting, inter alia, to have an extradition request from Israel determined on its merits. The decision of the magistrate to reject defence evidence has been the subject of parallel appeals through the courts up to the High Court of Australia and the administrative review mechanisms. So far all appeals have been unsuccessful. In my view, our proposed amendment to reapply the prima facie test will go a long way to overcoming concerns in this area. Of course, there never has been, nor should there be, a restriction on evidence that can be introduced, and which must be admitted by the magistrate, on technical issues covered by the legislation. Examples are: evidence on the question of identity, that a specified offence is a political offence, that other requirements of the legislation have not been complied with, et cetera.

Clause 19 sets out the matters about which a magistrate must be satisfied before a person is eligible to be extradited. Under sub-clause 19 (2), a specific onus is placed on a person whose extradition is sought to satisfy the magistrate `that there are substantial grounds for believing that there is an extradition objection' in relation to the alleged extradition offence. Clause 7 provides that an extradition objection arises, inter alia, where the alleged offence is a political offence or where the person's surrender is actually sought for the purpose of a prosecution on account of his or her race, religion, nationality or political opinions. By placing the onus on the accused to establish the existence of an extradition objection, the Bill merely attempts to codify the existing common law rule that a person seeking to claim the benefit of an exemption is required to adduce evidence of the existence of the relevant circumstances. This common law rule was confirmed by the High Court in the case of Commonwealth of Australia v. Reily. The Opposition has carefully examined the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on this proposal. For these reasons, we do not share the Committee's concerns.

Professor Shearer has also criticised the Bill because it does not include provisions for a general power in the courts to refuse extradition where it would be unjust, oppressive or incompatible with humanitarian considerations. This power is with the Attorney-General only. Professor Shearer takes the view that statutory power should also be with the courts, even though it is included in some of our treaties. Again I suggest that this is something that the Department could usefully look at and I will be interested to hear the Attorney-General's response.

On the question of the death penalty, the Extradition Bill before us today is intended to modernise Australia's extradition laws and thereby improve our ability to deal with fugitive offenders. However, the legislation introduces a new provision, paragraph 22 (3) (c), that will prevent the Attorney-General consenting to an extradition application where the death penalty can be imposed for any offence for which extradition has been requested unless Australia receives an undertaking from the requesting country that either the death penalty will not be imposed or, if imposed, will not be carried out if extradition is granted.

This provision could severely restrict Aus- tralia's ability to extradite the worst type of criminals to countries that impose the death penalty. Normally countries only impose the death penalty for the most serious crimes, such as murder and some terrorist activities. Not all governments have the capacity to override court orders, but even in countries where the power to commute the death penalty exists there may be sound reasons for a government not being able or wanting to give Australia an undertaking to do so. For example, the extradition requests might relate to a terrorist incident resulting in the deaths of many people, perhaps hundreds of people. A common terrorist tactic is to place bombs on planes or in crowded places such as airports, train stations, et cetera. In such cases not only would Australia not be able to extradite the terrorists for punishment, but we would also have no jurisdiction to put them on trial in this country except in the unlikely event that the terrorists were Australian nationals. The Government has really got itself into a pickle on this one.

On another level, a number of American States have reintroduced the death penalty and the trend in this direction is increasing yearly in the face of the escalating number of crimes of vio-lence, especially murder and rape. It is by no means certain that such jurisdiction would be prepared to do a deal with Australia. The ultimate result could well be that fugitive murderers from America and elsewhere come out to Australia and get off scot-free. It is unrealistic to allow this provision to proceed without a review of it. I encourage the Attorney-General to do so. It is not unrealistic to contemplate that Australia's famous tourist resorts may soon replace Spain's Costa Del Sol as the favourite safe haven for major international criminals.

I took the opportunity last weekend to raise this issue publicly, partly to bring the issue to the attention of the wider community, but also to give the Government an opportunity to prepare its position in advance of this debate. To my surprise, the Attorney-General's office came up with an instant response. However, I can only hope that the reply was not correctly reported. In short, the reported reply was to this effect, and I quote the Melbourne Age:

If someone was wanted for a serious crime overseas, he would simply be refused entry, or, if already in Australia, prosecuted for falsifying his visa application. Although this would be a relatively minor charge compared with blowing up an aircraft, the terrorist would not be able to get off scot-free.

This response would be laughable if the topic were not so serious. Surely the Attorney-Gene-ral's staff are aware by now that terrorists and big time criminals are able to roam the world at will using forged passports and secret bank accounts. Have they not yet got around to reading the plethora of royal commission reports which abound with stories about jet set criminals? The Government's response is to say that a slap over the wrist for some of these murderers is good enough. It is not good enough. The Attorney-General will just have to go back to the drawing board on this matter. It is an absolutely ludicrous proposition.

The reality is that with the way in which this legislation is drafted Australia could well find itself stuck with these undesirables if other countries are not prepared to do a deal on the death penalty. What a lovely way for those countries to rid themselves of such a problem. We need only to look at the Cuban example to see the horrendous consequences that might ensue. So far as the coalition is concerned, our real concern should be as to the sort of justice system that prevails in the requesting country. The proposal on the death penalty may sound fine but, of course, it is completely unnecessary because the Government already has a very wide residual discretion and, as we have now pointed out, it raises a potential problem of very considerable proportions.

In conclusion, the Opposition regards this legislation as an important measure and it has our general support. We will move several amendments, the most important of which seeks to reintroduce the prima facie evidence rule. This requires a review of legislation passed in 1985; we are aware of that. We think we should now face up to the ramifications of that. Unfortunately, in 1985 that legislation was rushed through the Parliament and this fundamental issue was basically not addressed. In proposing the amendment we have had the benefit of advice from an eminent Australian expert on extradition law-a professional whose advice has been relied upon by the Government itself on previous occasions. We put it forward in a constructive spirit and, as I have said, I look forward to the Government's response in particular to that matter. In regard to the two other amendments, we have had discussions with the Government and, again, we can debate those matters in the committee stage. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Extradition laws in abstraction I suppose are hardly the sort of matter which really inspires the imagin-ation of the public. However, over recent years, through media emphasis on figures such as Barton and Trimbole, Australia's extradition legislation has been brought into the public eye and it has been closely scrutinised. The slippery pursuit of figures such as Trimbole by Australian authorities through the complex maze of international law and politics has resulted in a tightening up of our own extradition mechanisms manifested in the enactment and amendment of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966. The Extradition Bill and the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill which are now before the House will further amend and consolidate these two Acts. Those amendments will provide additional safeguards against extradition from Australia, clarify the position on evidentiary requirements, and restrict the political offence exception to exclude certain crimes.

SPEECH.PARA: As I regard the last mentioned amendment as probably the most significant, I will address that issue first. As the House is fully aware, terrorism is an ever-increasing concern for all countries. We need only to cast our minds back to recent terrorist activity in the sabotage of a Korean Airlines flight and the Irish Republican Army attack to understand the grave measures that must be taken in order to protect the lives of innocent people. It is for this reason that I put my full support behind the amendment to the definition of `political offence' in clause 5 of the Extradition Bill, that being the interpretation clause. The exception itself originates in the Imperial Act of 1870, when it was considered necessary to protect various groups who were fighting against governments hostile to the British Empire. Over the years the definition of what actually constitutes an offence of a political character has been reappraised by the courts in the wake of the increase in violent activity by diverse political interest groups.

The problem which we now need to address is how to deal with those terrorists whose crimes are of such a reprehensible nature that they cannot be afforded the protection of the political exception rule to extradition and take refuge in other countries. This Bill, therefore, addresses the problem by drawing a distinction between serious types of offences and the motivation of offenders. It does this by excluding certain crimes which have been recognised by the international community in multilateral conventions, to which Australia is a party, as being of sufficient gravity to warrant exclusion from the political exception rule. These conventions relate to the safety of aircraft in civil aviation, the taking of hostages, genocide, torture, and the safety of internationally protected persons. The Bill provides scope for further regulations to be enacted for crimes that may be recognised in the future by subsequent treaties to which Australia becomes a party.

Therefore, in essence the Bill is a statutory testimony to Australia's ardent condemnation of violent terrorist activity and the harbouring of such persons on the grounds of ideological motivation. Whilst the Bill takes a firm approach to matters involving terrorism and the use of violence, it also introduces important new safeguards for those persons for whom extradition from Australia is sought. The first safeguard is the military offence exception which, although acknowledged by Australia in recently negotiated treaties, has never actually been expressly stated in statute. A military offence is one that relates exclusively to military law, such as insub-ordination or desertion. They are not offences that are covered by the ordinary criminal law. Under the new safeguard, a person will not be able to be extradited if the charge faced is purely under military law. Secondly, the torture exception protects a person from being extradited when there is a possibility that he might be subjected to torture. Under the convention against torture and other cruel, inhumane and degrading treatment or punishment, to which hopefully Australia will soon become a party, a person is not to be extradited unless the Attorney-General is satisfied that the person will not be subjected to torture.

The third safeguard precludes extradition to countries where the death penalty can be imposed for the offence for which the extradition is granted. The eligible person is to be surrendered for extradition only when the Attorney-General is satisfied that, where an offence is punishable by death, the extraditing country gives an assurance that the person will not be tried for the offence or, if tried, that the death penalty will not be imposed or, if it is imposed on the person, that it will not be carried out. In addition, the extraditing country must provide an assurance that the person will be dealt with only for the offence for which he is surrendered, lesser offences or an offence to which the Attorney-General consents. I understand the points being raised by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), in this regard. Of course, it is a dilemma because some countries impose the death penalty for certain types of offences. As the shadow Attorney-General points out, often the offences would be of a type for which extradition is sought, that is, very serious offences, such as murder or terrorism. However, I believe it is correct for the Australian Government to take a strong stand and not to accede to a request for extradition where the death penalty is a possibility. I do not believe that the murder of an individual can be justified by any crime. I appreciate that other people may have a different view on that stand, but I am happy that the Attorney-General will have the power in the Act not to allow extradition unless he can be satisfied that arrangements can be put into place whereby the person must be dealt with by appropriate punishment, but I do not believe that the death penalty is ever an appropriate punishment.

The final matter I wish to address is the clarification of the 1985 amendment which gives effect to the common law principle that extradition proceedings are not trials to determine guilt or innocence. The 1985 amendment provided that a person was not entitled to produce evidence to negate an allegation that the person actually had committed an act or omission in respect of which the surrender of the person was requested. The provision gave effect to the common law principle that extradition proceedings are not trials to determine guilt or innocence. The 1985 amendment overturns this presumption of innocence in some sense and this Bill seeks to clarify the position, at least as far as Commonwealth countries are concerned, in respect of evidence required for the surrender of a fugitive. It also unifies throughout Australia the position and the test to be applied in the first instance, at least, by a magistrate's court. Of course, this is important where co-offenders are arrested in different States. I suppose there is some possibility that different magistrates in different States, faced with the same evidence, could come to different conclusions. That could happen, but at least if uniform tests applied in all the Australian courts that hear extradition proceedings the possibility of different results would be eliminated. Therefore, I believe that the provisions should have the support of the House.

I have addressed what I believe to be some of the main points of this Bill. It is an extensive piece of legislation. To a large degree, it codifies the law of extradition in this country, and as such it is to be commended because, as the shadow Minister quite rightly pointed out, the existing legislation had been amended to the extent that it was extremely difficult to work through, even, I imagine, for many legal practitioners. The bringing together of those laws into one piece of legislation will make things easier for both solicitors and, I suppose more importantly, the courts and the fugitives who will be tried under this legislation. Generally, I welcome the support for this legislation that was indicated by the Opposition. I believe that the legislation will enhance Australia's position in this difficult field, and I commend same to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate the Extradition Bill 1987 and the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. I would like to take this opportunity to outline briefly the purpose of the Extradition Bill 1987, and I will then direct my attention to one aspect of that Bill which I believe really requires further consideration by the Government and the Parliament. I am glad to have the opportunity to be able to address the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on this matter, as this is a very serious question. The Extradition Bill consolidates Australia's extradition laws by combining the operations of the former Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966. Of course, that process involves the elimination of unnecessary duplication, the removal of inconsistencies and the remedying of proven deficiencies, and it follows an exhaustive review. The explanatory memorandum states that Bill has a number of specific purposes:

SPEECH.PARA: provides that persons accused or convicted of terrorist type offences shall not be entitled to the benefit of the political offence exception to extradition;

permits prosecution in Australia, in lieu of extradition, in circumstances where an Australian citizen would be eligible to be extradited to a country which will not extradite its nationals to Australia but which prosecutes its nationals for offences in respect of which Australia requests extradition;

provides that a person serving a sentence of imprisonment in Australia for an offence against a law in force in Australia may be temporarily surrendered to another country to stand trial there for an extradition offence then returned to Australia to complete his or her sentence here and ultimately be re-surrendered to serve any sentence imposed as a result of that overseas trial;

permits, with the consent of the person sought, extradition for offences which could not normally be the subject of extradition because the sentence which may be passed in respect of them is not sufficiently severe.
ensures that extradition cannot be granted for military offences which are not also offences against the ordinary criminal law.

In terms of that broad outline, the Opposition has no objection to this legislation. In fact, there have been changes in recent years in relation to extradition which I suppose this Bill is now codifying. But when the changes are clearly spelled out and are understood, they give rise for concern. I guess that I have been remiss to the extent that I, as a member of the Opposition, previously allowed to go unchallenged certain provisions dealing with the question of prima facie evidence of the commission of an offence overseas being adduced here in Australia before we surrender our citizens. After reading clause 19 of the Bill, which deals with the determination of eligibility for surrender, I became very cognisant of what we had done in the recent past. This is one of the reasons that the Opposition will be proposing an amendment to clause 19 which deals with the provision of prima facie evidence of guilt being submitted here before people are in fact surrendered.

I recognise-and the Attorney may well answer this point-that there are certain procedural steps that might be taken. There is a capacity for people to apply administratively in certain circumstances if they think that there was inadequate evidence of guilt. Perhaps an Attorney might be persuaded to act, but I do not think Australians ought to be put at risk of being surrendered to an overseas country for a trial without prima facie evidence of guilt and that question being reviewable only in a sense here administratively. I believe that our Attorneys are conscientious but, in accordance with the rule of law that I believe ought to apply, Australian citizens ought not be put on trial, and incur the expense of a trial, overseas without being able to obtain the same sorts of elementary rights that they have in relation to serious offences here in Australia. Generally speaking, here in Australia if one is to be put on trial for a serious offence one has to be brought before a magistrate and there has to be a preliminary hearing at which the Crown adduces prima facie evidence of guilt.

Clause 19 (1) talks about a person being on remand under section 15 of the Act; the Attorney-General giving notice; application being made to a magistrate by or on behalf of the person or the extradition country concerned for proceedings to be conducted; and the magistrate considering whether the person and the extradition country have had reasonable time in which to prepare for the conduct of proceedings. The clause states:

. . . the magistrate shall conduct proceedings to determine whether the person is eligible for surrender in relation to the extradition offence or extradition offences for which surrender of the person is sought by the extradition country.
It sets out the circumstances in which the magistrate may conduct an inquiry. Clause (2) sets out the basis upon which that inquiry is to be considered. It states:
For the purposes of subsection (1), the person is only eligible for surrender in relation to an extradition offence for which surrender of the person is sought by the extradition country if:
(a) the supporting documents in relation to the offence have been produced to the magistrate;
That is not prima facie evidence. A person merely has to produce supporting documents. Clause (2) continues:

(b) where this Act applies in relation to the extradition country subject to any limitations, conditions, exceptions or qualifications that require the production to the magistrate of any other documents-those documents have been produced to the magistrate;

(c) the magistrate is satisfied that, if the conduct of the person constituting the offence in relation to the extradition country, or equivalent conduct, had taken place in the part of Australia where the proceedings are being conducted and at the time at which the extradition request in relation to the person was received, that conduct or that equivalent conduct would have constituted an extradition offence in relation to that part of Australia; and
(d) the person does not satisfy the magistrate that there are substantial grounds for believing that there is an extradition objection in relation to the offence.

Clause (3) defines what are `supporting documents'. The term `supporting documents' means a duly authenticated warrant issued by the extradition country; it is not prima facie evidence. Clause (3) (b) states:
. . . if the offence is an offence of which the person has been convicted-such duly authenticated documents as provide evidence of:
(i) the conviction;
(ii) the sentence imposed or the intention to impose a sentence; and
(iii) the extent to which a sentence imposed has not been carried out . . .

I find it extraordinary that in my case, for instance, although I might not have even been overseas somebody might produce a warrant issued from another country in relation to an offence that might be said to have taken place. I cannot challenge at that point whether or not I had even been overseas at that time. I could be put to the expense of a trial in another jurisdiction and all that that involves in a judicial system that hopefully might be the same as ours. The case might be before a jury that would be empanelled abroad. I might be put on trial-even though I may not even have been there in that country-because somebody produces supporting documents.

I might be naive, but I would have thought that our courts ought to be able to look at the fundamental question as to whether or not I was overseas at the relevant time, whether or not there was some substantial case for me to answer in the terms that we understand it here in our own courts before we commit people to trial. This can happen to any Australian citizen. We are not talking about people from abroad who might be in Australia who are trying to hide, although it may well apply to such people. We are talking about any Australian citizen for whom extradition is sought. A foreign court might want to deal with an alleged offence that may have been dealt with in our courts.

I am not alone in my concern about this. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has spoken at length from documents provided to the Opposition by some people with some experience in this area. I speak particularly of Professor Shearer of the University of New South Wales who wrote a very helpful document on this matter. He reveals the basis upon which this situation has arisen. He makes it clear that in his view the situation of Australian citizens under the Bill is significant in relation to evidence of guilt and that the Bill is most unsatisfactory and requires closer scrutiny. He puts the position that I understand existed until 1985 and, I must say, until I read this Bill, thought still operated in Australia. He states:

Until 1985 all foreign countries were required under the Act, as it was then worded, and under the relevant treaties, to present evidence of the facts alleged against the fugitive. This evidence was reviewed by the Australian magistrate who had to consider, under the tests applied within the magistrate's normal jurisdiction, whether the evidence would be sufficient to warrant placing the person on trial, in other words a prima facie case. The same rule applied to extradition requests from Commonwealth countries (except for New Zealand, which under the simplified procedures retained in the present Bill is treated for extradition purposes rather like a State of Australia).

The requirement that prima facie evidence of guilt be produced against an accused fugitive has been a feature of extradition laws in this country, and other parts of the Commonwealth, since 1843. Its clear purpose-
he puts it much more nicely than I have been able to put it to date-

has been to ensure that persons were not in danger of being sent thousands of miles to another country for trial, perhaps in strange conditions, for an alleged crime merely on the bare allegation of a foreign government. A review of the evidence also indirectly re-inforced the other protections of the rights of the fugitive given by extradition law, such as the prohibition against extradition for politically motivated offences, since such circumstances might not emerge without a full review of the case.

We recognise that there are certain circumstances such as political matters that are not going to be involved. I am not concerned about political matters because while people might be sought for political reasons, if a government is determined to obtain an Australian citizen in Australia and to put him on trial overseas in another jurisdiction, if it is prepared to go so far as to knock up a case against such an Australian citizen, I do not think it would do so in what might appear to be an obviously politically motivated area. It could well do so in another area altogether. Professor Shearer continued:

The prima facie case requirement was removed from the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (but not from the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act), in 1985. It remained a requirement thereafter only if the relevant treaty specified the production of such evidence.

I acknowledge that there are certain circumstances in which prima facie evidence is required, but it is interesting that in the Commonwealth countries that have the same legal tradition as our country and are more likely to apply the same principles of justice the prima facie evidence test will operate. However when we are dealing with a country that operates under a different legal system, that may not have the same consciousness of principles of justice that we see as being important, we have allowed the question to go merely to the production of documents, as I read earlier from clause 19. Professor Shearer continued:
A number of new treaties, or amendments to existing treaties, have been concluded since 1985 to remove the evidentiary requirement.
He continued-and this ought to be clearly understood:
This is an overreaction to the problems of extradition procedure and represents a threat, in particular, to the rights of Australian citizens charged with offences abroad.

I think he was making the point, which I would make, that we were so anxious to obtain extradition of some people who had left Australia that we were prepared to give away important rights in relation to the protection of other Australian citizens in regard to offences which may or may not have been committed abroad, but about which allegations have been raised that they have been committed abroad, warrants have been issued, and so on. We have given away such rights that Australian citizens might have been able to rely upon in the expectation that we might be able to get back the Trimboles of this world-although in that case, no longer of this world. I think people will appreciate the analogy I am making. We were anxious to negotiate these treaties; therefore, we gave away some of the protection that we would have ordinarily seen as being important to all Australians. Professor Shearer continued:

The justification given for such a precipitate shift in Australia's legislative and treaty practice of extradition away from the common law tradition to the civil law tradition is that those countries experience difficulty in satisfying the prima facie evidence requirement. The civil law's inquisitorial approach to criminal procedure is said to be unsuited to the production of evidence in a form suited to the courts of Australia which follow the accusatorial style of procedure. In short, our system of justice is found inconvenient by those countries.
He made the following point-and I would make it also:

Mere convenience should not, however, be the determining factor. It is surely absurd that Australians under the present Bill can be sent back to Britain or Canada only on the production of a prima facie case, to the satisfaction of an Australian magistrate, but can be sent to Germany or Japan, without any evidence of guilt at all having to be produced. All that is required under the present Bill in such cases are the documents describing but not evidencing the offences set out in clause 19. This point is altogether disguised in the Bill and would not be apparent to even a careful reader.
Interestingly, it was apparent to me and it was one of the reasons that this matter was raised in our own counsels and further pursued. He continued:

But the truth is that it is intended to make regulations under the Act that will preserve the prima facie case requirement in relation to Commonwealth countries, in order to maintain reciprocity under the London Scheme of 1966 . . . but that regulations made under the newer treaties with foreign countries will contain no such evidentiary requirement.
It is wrong that such a fundamental aspect of extradition should not be addressed in the body of the Bill itself but is relegated to the regulation-making power.

Moreover it must be remembered that under the present Bill the Attorney-General has the sole discretion to decide whether the extradition of an Australian citizen should be refused or allowed. This aspect of the extradition process is not reviewable by any court or tribunal.

In other words, whatever confidence I have in the Attorney may not be the confidence that one might have in whoever replaces him from this side or his own side in the future. He or she may not have the same careful regard for the principles of justice. Should an extradition in a case involving myself or any other member of parliament or any other Australian citizen be left unreviewable, to be decided administratively? In such a case a person, simply on the basis of an accusation or a warrant, could be put to trial even if he was not overseas at the relevant time, and that matter is not able to be reviewed. Professor Shearer was very helpful. He offered this view:

The better solution is to retain the prima facie case requirement for all extradition and to make provision for dispensation from certain evidentiary rules of evidence that presently complicate the proceedings from point of view of the civil law countries.

He says that appropriate changes should be devised in the way in which Canada, in looking at the same question, has been considering such changes. The Opposition is proposing an amendment-the honourable member for Flinders has proposed it-to clause 19. I urge the Government to look very seriously at the proposed sub-clauses and to indicate, if it cannot accept the amendment at this time, that before the matter is finally disposed of by the Senate, appropriate amendments will be made to ensure that this simple protection is available to all Australian citizens. Extradition is not a matter which should be seen as relevant only to those people who are visiting Australia and who might try to find refuge here. It is something that is relevant to all Australian citizens, all permanent residents. They could be faced with a situation in which they are put to trial, in much the same way as they could be faced with a trial at any time in Australia, and they would expect to have the protection of our courts. Unfortunately, this Bill denies them that protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with some surprise that I found myself on the speakers list for the debate on the Extradition Bill 1987. It is a tribute to the big heart of our Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), because he knows that I have some strong qualms about this legislation. The Bill, in general, can only be supported, but there are a few things that need some consideration. I notice that purely military offences are not extraditable. This, of course, means that only offences such as desertion or insubordination would be covered. It certainly would not cover military offences involving violence or criminal dealings by members of the armed forces. I also notice that we do not extradite to countries where the Attorney is not convinced that torture will not be applied or where torture is regularly used. One can only commend this. Of course, how one determines this is a little more difficult to work out. But, in general, who could complain?

SPEECH.PARA: The death penalty raises some interesting questions, because there is no doubt that most countries apply the death penalty for the more heinous crimes, the worst sort of offences. Superficially, it would appear that we will protect people who commit the more serious offences but offer no protection to those who commit offences of a lesser nature. In reality, of course, the fears expressed by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), are unfounded because people who got into Australia after committing such crimes would only have done so by lying. The powers under the Migration Act allow those people to be deported. They can be deported completely independently of any extradition proceedings. So the reality is that that would not occur. So to my mind it seems to be irrelevant and should not be in the Bill for that reason. It seems a little incongruous that we are prepared to pontificate upon this point, based on our abhorrence of the death penalty, yet we are prepared to throw out of the window the need for a prima facie case to be established, which is fundamental to our law and basic to our culture. I would say this deficiency is a far greater affront to our culture than the consideration that some other countries impose the death penalty.

I do not think the safeguards in the Bill go anywhere near far enough and I think we should be looking at two other points. Firstly, the Attorney should take into consideration whether legal aid is available. Very often people are extradited to countries where they will be in a foreign jurisdiction without legal aid available to them. With the best will in the world they will not get a fair trial and it is absurd to suggest that they will.

Another amendment to the Bill I would like to see is one which the Attorney-General told me he does not have the power to make. I do not hold his view because it is my view that our Attorney-General is omnipotent. The Attorney told me he does not have the power to grant bail to someone for whom extradition is sought. I think this is outrageous and it is also silly. It is very expensive for this country and it greatly offends the civil liberties of the person involved. I think the determining factor should be whether the person is likely to try to escape or avoid custody. Where the Attorney-General can be convinced that would not be the case bail should be granted while litigation is in process.

I raise that because of the Orionia affair, in which two American citizens sought by Israel have been in gaol for something like 16 months now. I have been told, `It is really their own fault. They keep using the process of our law to avoid deportation'. I think they are entitled to do that. They are obviously very scared of being extradited to Israel, where they will have no legal aid and will be in a foreign jurisdiction where, I believe, they have great cause to believe that justice will not be available to them. This is a very important area.

I think the absence in clause 11 (5) (b) of a requirement that a prima facie case be established stems largely from the Trimbole case and the embarrassment the Government found itself in when we were unable to extradite Trimbole from Ireland. I do not believe that the Government should have felt any embarrassment at all; if there was any embarrassment due it was due entirely to the incompetence of the previous Government that had years and years to keep these treaties up to date but never attempted to do so. The embarrassment certainly was not the embarrassment of this Government. I believe we threw the baby out with the bath water in not requiring this level of substantiation.

Harking back to the Orionia case, the documents presented by the Israeli Government were all self-serving; they were not evidence and there is no way they could be construed as evidence. There was a warrant for the arrest of these people but the warrant was issued after they had left Israel and it was never delivered. The other evidence was of a similar nature. There were statements from people who were purporting to be company directors. In short, it was a very messy civil litigation for which there should have been no extradition process. The Attorney-General has told me that he believes it was a civil litigation. The Israeli Government chose to make it criminal and we have simply gone along with it. That is simply not good enough and to me there is clear evidence there of a great injustice.

I have had extensive talks with the Attorney's departmental officers and I was singularly unimpressed with their attitude to this whole thing. I might also say that I was very unimpressed with the enthusiasm, the alacrity, with which the Commonwealth police chose to act on the request of the Israeli Government. Just a small delay would have seen these people revictualled in Australia on their way to Vanuatu and it would not have been a problem of ours. It is one which I do not believe Australia necessarily should have been involved with. I find myself with grave disquiet about that case. It makes me very cynical when I hear people talk about civil liberties and human rights when I know the lack of thought and lack of consideration that were given in this case. It was a civil case and at no stage were these people in default with money. When they left Israel in fact they were paid up 12 months in advance. It may very well be that 12 months down the track they intended to default, but the fact is they had not defaulted and no crime had been committed at that stage.

I think the whole Orionia affair reflects no credit on this country and it is an episode of which I am particularly ashamed. We have this unseemly spectacle wherein these people will have been in custody for probably two years by the time the extradition process winds its way to completion. They will then be extradited to Israel, face a court in which they will not be able to afford legal aid, in an environment where they probably will not even understand the proceedings of the court, and will probably find themselves in gaol for another three or four years. But then I suppose one can excuse this on the grounds that they are only Americans!

I find myself often concerned that Australia is tending to go down the American road of litigation. We are tending to become a nation of litigants and this is, I think, because lawyers basically are like the environmentalists: they are never satisfied. The more they are given, the more they want. They have an inordinate ability to complicate things and to be able to extract, for their own benefit, reimbursement for these complications. I think the Attorney-General has done a great job in simplifying the wording of this Bill. We have to give serious consideration to sub-clause 11 (5) (b). Uncontroverted evidence is a very difficult area. I do not see that one is predetermining a trial by examining documents to determine whether they are evidence. If documents are not evidence, they have nothing to do with the case and they should not even be considered.

I believe that common law is a good system by and large and nothing to be ashamed of. I do not feel that we need to lower our standards to accommodate any inconveniences that may appear for those nations that operate under civil law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you support our amendment on the prima facie ground.

—I must say that I am very taken with the honourable member's amendment: I think it does need serious consideration. It puts me in a dilemma which obviously will test my mettle. However, I would have felt much better about it if the Opposition had ever taken an interest in this particular case, which it clearly did not do. It did not do so because the whole thing was just too inconvenient for it at the time. I conclude with these remarks: the honourable member for Flinders would very well fit my definition of a lawyer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate because of concerns about this legislation somewhat similar to those expressed by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). As a lawyer, I share his non-lawyer concern that people sought to be taken to other countries for trial in other countries should be sent abroad only if our high standards of justice and the enforcement of the law are complied with. As has been pointed out by my colleagues on this side of the House, the difficulty that we find in the present circumstances has arisen because there is a fundamental difference in approach between the common law, on which our legal system is based, and the civil law, upon which the laws of many other countries are based. They are two great systems, but they approach the solution of legal problems in a quite different way. As has been pointed out by my colleagues, the common law based its enforcement of the criminal law on a territorial basis, and said that if someone committed a crime within the territory or the realm, he would be tried within the realm, and if he escaped from the realm, the authorities would seek to bring him back to the country. It was on this basis that the early history of extradition treaties and arrangements was developed.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in the civil law system, the approach is that if one of the country's citizens is in breach of a law, whether within the realm or elsewhere in the world, he is in breach of the law of the realm and will be prosecuted when he comes back within the jurisdiction, or the authorities will seek to extradite him in certain circumstances, and certainly will seek to extradite him in relation to offences that were committed within the territory. But those countries will never allow their citizens to be extradited to another country in which they have committed an offence. So here we are, faced with a situation where we adopt the view that if an Australian citizen commits or is alleged to have committed a crime overseas, we will, under our approach to the law, allow that Australian citizen to be extradited to be dealt with in the country in which the offence was committed, a country from which he may have fled and returned back here. But if a person from a civil law country such as France, Italy, Spain, or many other countries, commits a crime in Australia, flees Australia and goes back to France, for example, under the application of the civil law, the French authorities will never surrender that French citizen for trial in Australia. Whether they then try that French citizen because the crime committed in Australia is deemed to be a crime in French law, is a matter for the discretions that apply within their legal system.

The other principle that we have always tended to apply is one that says we will treat in our law everyone in the same way. In the light of that conflict between the civil law countries and the common law countries, we have to question that, for if we do not, we downgrade the significance of Australian citizenship for we give less protection to Australians than other countries give to their citizens. In making these remarks, no one, I least of all, would suggest that someone who has been in breach of the criminal law should get away with it. My concern is that there are cases where people are alleged to have committed crimes they have not committed. We have a legal system that tests that question. In a trial within our own country on serious crime, the prosecuting authorities have to establish a prima facie case.

The question at issue here is whether people who are regarded as fugitives by some other country, and who are found and arrested in Australia, should be returned to the requesting country simply on the basis of some documents that describe the alleged offence. It might be all right for someone from a civil law country to be sent back on the basis of the documents of record. We may be prepared to accept that under certain circumstances and say that we will vary our approach to the law by saying that, insofar as the law of Australia is concerned, it will apply universally, but where it relates to offences committed in other countries by citizens of that country, we will allow that country's law to apply, subject to concerns of a more serious nature that are addressed in this legislation.

In those cases we may be prepared to vary our approach to Australian laws, but we should not vary that approach in relation to Australia's citizens, whether born here or with citizenship conferred upon them. They should get the protection of Australia's legal system. Therefore, I strongly support the amendments to be moved by my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I would hope that this sort of issue is one on which the members of this Parliament can be truly members of Parliament and I view it as a matter of important legal consequences affecting Australian citizens and others. Having heard the honourable member for Kalgoorlie speak as he did, I would hope that he will have the courage to go to his parliamentary leaders and ask whether, on a matter such as this, he could be freed from the normal Caucus view-he and others of his colleagues. I think that there would be some who would have the sort of concerns that we on this side of the House are expressing in this regard.

I do not believe that we should surrender Australian citizens who are alleged to have committed crimes in other countries unless sufficient evidence is presented before Australian courts to satisfy the normal prima facie requirement, subject perhaps to some watering down of that requirement, insofar as the evidentiary rules are concerned. I can understand how it might be difficult for some other countries to satisfy common law evidentiary requirements. Therefore, while giving those people the protection of the prima facie principle, the evidentiary watering down would not significantly lessen the protection that the prima facie rule test applies. The only other way to go would be for us to adopt the civil law approach, and that would be to say that, so far as we are concerned, where Australian citizens commit an offence anywhere else in the world, we will try them here and bring evidence from the countries in which they committed that offence. That could be argued, and a strong case could be made for it. We could give to Australian citizens the right of the protection of Australian laws and if they breach the law of this country or laws of other countries, we should perhaps consider giving Australia's courts that jurisdiction that is now to be conferred, by section 45 of this Bill, in all cases.

This Bill goes part of the way. It says that, under certain circumstances, we will give Australian citizens the right to be tried in this country in respect of offences committed overseas. That is to be made available only on a discretionary basis. I imagine that great pressure will be brought to bear on the Australian Government and the Australian Attorney-General to grant extradition because it will be argued that it will be very expensive to conduct the trial in Australia and very difficult to bring witnesses from around the world. In my view to say that the clause 45 provision should be made available only at the discretion of the Attorney-General is not a sufficient protection of Australian citizens when that clause is coupled with our departure from the requirement of the prima facie case test before we will allow an Australian citizen to be extradited overseas.

I must say that I have a somewhat lesser concern for those people I would perceive as fugitive, that is, citizens of other countries who seek entry to Australia because they think that by being in Australia they will avoid the rigours of the law of the country in which they committed the crime. In most cases, it is the law of the country of their own citizenship. If they are citizens of another country and would not be subject to the acts to which I have referred, such as torture and certain other penalties, I think that they should be extradited to their own country. I would not have nearly as much concern if such people were extradited under the evidentiary provisions of their country, merely on the record.

In this legislation the difficulty is to find a means of meshing the quite contradictory principles of two great systems of law. Given the extensive spread of the civil law system and the great protection that countries with such a system give to their citizens, I am alarmed to think that we might be continuing to downgrade the value and the protection afforded Australian citi-zenship because the Government is not prepared to give serious consideration to the Opposition's request that we reinstate in our extradition requirements the establishment of a prima facie case before an Australian citizen is extradited to any country. As the honourable member for Flinders pointed out, that is a requirement in regard to certain treaty arrangements with Commonwealth countries. Therefore, why should it not be a mandatory requirement in the case of extradition requests to other countries around the world?

As I have already said, it is a matter of interest that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie should have spoken so forcefully in relation to a particular case because, as he reads the evidence, it is a matter of some concern as to whether a foreign country has trumped up some charges relating to people now held under extradition warrants in this country. He has salved his conscience by saying that, because some members on this side of the House have not taken the same personal interest in the case that he has, this is a justification for allowing similar cases to occur, perhaps next year, the year after or some time further in the future. He does not have the political courage to put his vote where his mouth is and vote for the reintroduction in this legislation of the prima facie requirement. However, if he cannot apply that to all cases where extradition orders are required, I would urge him to vote for its reintroduction particularly in the case of all Australian citizens who are alleged to have committed crimes in other countries.

I do not believe that putting that requirement back into the legislation would mean any lessening of the enforcement of the proper legal procedures against people who have, in fact, committed crimes. By putting it back into the legislation it would certainly protect those Australian citizens who, through some circumstance or another, find themselves confronted by what can be described only as an ill-prepared allegation or a trumped up charge. What the Government is proposing to do in the Bill now before the House is to put Australian citizens at risk of being extradited to countries, whose legal systems they would not understand, on the basis of charges which lack any substance whatsoever. Therefore, I urge the Government and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie to reconsider this position and to take the action necessary to ensure that the important amendment moved by the honourable member for Flinders is incorporated in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Basically, the main objection raised in this debate on the Extradition Bill and the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill seems to relate to the fact that in this country we have apparently almost unilaterally abandoned the prima facie requirement relating to extradition. I want to set the record straight. Firstly, it is recognised that we have been able to enter into a number of treaties which we were not able to enter into before because we would not agree to adopt what the European countries wanted. I refer to those countries whom we recognise as having a fair system of justice. Those countries did not want to be put to the trouble and difficulty of having to produce sworn evidence, as the British have always insisted. Those countries wanted us to accept that when the government of any one of them made a statement as to the nature and details of the offence that would be accepted. We agreed with that.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem the British have faced is that they have never been able to get extradition treaties with European countries. We can understand the position of the British who, on the basis of common law, insisted that there be sworn evidence. Let me make the further point that the prima facie case was never on the basis that the evidence would be subject to any test or cross-examination. It merely had to be sworn before a judge or something of that kind. Therefore, while the British were in the position of applying that sort of standard, none of the European countries actually would comply with it. Therefore, there was no chance of any person entering Britain from Europe being extradited back. The British would not accept anybody else's standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you limit the change?

—I ask the honourable member to bear with me. I was at a conference of Commonwealth Ministers in Harare. All of them-except the British-said that it was about time that they abandoned the outmoded British standard. I will mention also that the Canadians might have had second thoughts. We are actually in a position now of having bilateral arrangements with all Commonwealth countries because now we do not have the requirement of sworn evidence as against a statement by the relevant government as to the nature of the offence and its particulars. Therefore, if the Government were to accept the suggestion that it has done something wrong-I submit that it has not-we would place in jeopardy all the treaties we have with European countries. The requirement of sworn evidence is not now the standard. I understand that the British themselves are about to change their own rules.
—Yes, but not with everybody.

—The honourable gentleman has quite effectively said `not with everybody'. We do not have treaties with everybody. We could get into a nice argument about a matter that was raised here by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I respect the views of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. I do not deviate from that. However, his point is that even though we have a treaty with a country we do not need to respect the laws of that country. He is entitled to take that view. However, it puts us in all sorts of difficulties as to whether we should have a treaty in the first place, if that is the position. If we apply the same standard, why would we have a treaty with any of these countries? In fact we do not have treaties with the Eastern bloc countries because we do not recognise their systems of justice. Going back to the conference at Harare, at which there were representatives of 40-odd countries sitting around the table, quite frankly, the only one out was the United Kingdom. That was on the basis that at that stage it could not see any reason why it should change its standard. But it had to acknowledge that there is not a lot of difference between a reputable country-a country with which one has a treaty, a country which one acknowledges has principles of justice-on the one hand saying, `We want a citizen returned to us', and giving a statement about the citizen's conduct, the particulars of the offence and the fact that it is a crime within that country's criminal code, and on the other hand saying, `In addition, we want some sworn evidence'. In other words, we are not going to accept what the country says; we are going to accept some form of sworn evidence which the country is not accustomed to getting and which in fact in many cases has no procedures to obtain. If honourable members opposite say, `That is the British standard we inherited; we used to be part of the British Empire and therefore we are going to stick with that', we will have no treaties.

SPEECH.PARA: The position in Australia is that when a magistrate has the matter before him, he has to be satisfied that the request from a country is a legitimate request, it is in order and it meets the requirements of our standard; that is, that it is a country with which we have a treaty. In accordance with the treaty we look at the requests of a country, particularly from the point of view of the identity of a person. The person concerned can give evidence to the effect that the wrong person is involved and that should satisfy the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who seemed to be concerned that he might be subject to extradition. I do not know why he thinks that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a worry.

—It is a worry for him, but it is not a worry for me. If it is a question of mistaken identity, that evidence certainly can be submitted and the other questions can be dealt with on the basis of the nature of the offence. It is acknowledged that a person cannot give evidence of innocence because we have no facilities to try each case in Australia. That would be quite ridiculous.
—I said that.

—The honourable member did say that. I am not saying that everything he said was wrong. The point that I am making is that extradition is an interesting aspect of a legal procedure where another country has requested that a citizen, usually of that country, be returned to it. We make the point in the Extradition Bill 1987, which all honourable members have applauded, that our citizens do not have to be returned. I assume that under the old system the British were prepared to return their citizens if they were obviously satisfied in terms of what they deemed to be the standard of proof. They have never had to face up to this undertaking because there was never an actual chance of anybody making a request to the satisfaction of the British system. But now that there is some comity through international treaties and arrangements under which certain countries recognise each other-for example, the free world-a country is expected to abide by those standards because it accepts the principles and standards of justice that those countries apply. Opposition members cannot come into this chamber now and suddenly say, `I made a dreadful mistake. I was rushed into this in 1985 because obviously I had not read the Bill properly. I now want to say that all that was wrong'.
—It was.

—The honourable gentleman says that it is wrong. If it is wrong, the British are now apparently going to go down the wrong road.
