What are Opposition members trying to do in respect of alleged sworn evidence being tested by cross-examination? What is the basic difference between a government submitting evidence and those opposite saying, `Well, it is really not in the right form. I want it sworn before a judge or something.'? There is no question of carrying out a trial or testing the evidence by cross-examination. We are talking about witnesses who are not here and never have been here. They were never available under the British system either. Are we to try and make an assessment of the evidence on mere paperwork following a request from a government? I point out to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie-he does not necessarily accept what I am saying-that there was a request from a government. Married to that request was a court order made by a judge saying that this was to be the position, that a certain vessel was not to be removed. In other words, it was not just done because somebody thought that these people were Christians and, therefore, ought to be dealt with in a certain way. That is the problem we are facing. Again, in fairness to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, I admire his application to this task. It is a bit unfair to say that these people are in gaol because we cannot let them out. They were not in gaol until such time as they were found to be subject to extradition. Since then-quite legitimately from their point of view but, nevertheless, because of the nature of the proceedings and the number of them-they have been going to, and are still entitled to go to, every court in Australia. I will not say any more because the matter is still sub judice. That is the reason for having an extradition order being made. The law is that a person is not able to get bail. In fact, in many cases-it does not apply to these people-we do not find people after bail has been granted in the first instance. We just had a recent example in Melbourne where a judge legitimately granted bail and the person concerned, who is the subject of an extradition application, is no longer around. I suppose it is a normal human reaction to say, `Why should I stay if I can leave?'. And that is what people do. But it does create a sense of embarrassment for us when we lose the citizen of a country which has produced evidence and with which we have a treaty.
—I agree with you; I said so.
—The honourable member is right again because he is agreeing with me.
—That is twice.
—Yes, that is two shots for the honourable member today.
—Two out of two.

—It is two out of two. I think that all honourable members basically understand the problems of nations and the difficulties of dealing with alleged criminal behaviour. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said to me, `Look, you are really going to encourage every bandit in the world to come here and because they are liable to the death penalty you will not be able to get rid of them'. That is not really the situation. In most cases-I am reminded of the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act-people who commit crimes, such as hijacking, are dealt with in Australia. They are punished here. That is the position and that is the obligation under Article 4 of that Act, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Each Contracting State shall take such measures as may be necessary to establish its jurisdiction. . .

In other words, there is an obligation to deal with such a person. That is the position here. I acknowledge the fact that a country may say, `Look, if you extradite our citizen, we will carry out the death penalty'. I am barred from saying that I cannot extradite that person. But I would not be anxious to extradite a person when our own laws do not agree with the death penalty. For example, there have been cases such as this in respect of California. One finds as a matter of course that all these countries, because of their sense of justice, are prepared to say, `Look, we will give you an undertaking that the person will be dealt with, but the death penalty will not be carried out'. We accept that. We are not having any troubles with this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why tie your hands? Why introduce it if you are not having any troubles?

—We are not really tying our hands. I will make another point for the honourable member for Flinders. He probably will not agree with me, so that will make the score two out of three. The honourable member seems to be suggesting that because of what is involved with extradition, there is no such thing as deportation. I am not going to go into the argument--
—You cannot have de facto extradition.

—We cannot have it in the principles of the High Court. That is the other factor. We then come to what the High Court would say-and there are decisions on this-in respect of whether a person is entitled to resist deportation for other reasons. It has got nothing to do with extradition; it has got everything to do with deportation. Deportation is not negated by this issue and the honourable member for Flinders has got to understand that. Under the law of our land, there are other principles that would prevent deportation. The honourable member wants to conveniently confine his argument by saying `This is a great opportunity. They are all going to read this particular section and they will all be galloping over here and the Attorney-General will not be able to get rid of them'. I do not think that is the position at all. I might not be able to extradite them if the country says that it is going to kill them when they come back. If that is the issue--
—They are not going to say they are going to kill them because they have not tried them yet and we are satisfied with their justice system. So that statement is not worth anything.

—Unfortunately, the honourable member has used his 20 minutes. If he will only give me another seven minutes to finish, I will be able to say that, whilst I do not agree with him, countries always, because of their systems of justice, give a fair assessment as to what they will do. These countries do not say that they will kill these people; they do say that they will try them. They say, `We will not carry out the death penalty', and we accept the position. It still leaves us with the other position where those citizens could be deported anyway and they certainly would not be subject to extradition. But it does not mean that they will stay here forever simply because somebody wants to extradite them. We have said to these other countries that we cannot do this because they will not give us an undertaking. This brings into play another set of principles in the Migration Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certainly giving clear cut decisions to the whole Australian nation. I do not think it is the opinion of the Australian nation that people should be subject to the death penalty. Of course, we acknowledge that if our citizens are caught overseas we can do little about it. But when people are here we do not apply the death penalty; we adopt a position, which I think reflects public opinion in Australia, where we do not send them back for execution.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are mixing up foreign systems and the Australian system. You are not separating the issue.

—I am separating the issue that the Opposition will not separate. A country with which we have had treaties is prepared to be flexible about this difficult matter. It does not mean that people go unpunished. The Opposition is so inflexible that it is demanding-the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) said this in his own statement-that we go back to the old British system of prima facie evidence which would negate half of our treaties. That would mean that we would get nobody back here. That is how silly it is. It is legitimate for honourable members opposite to say that, when I came into this portfolio, we were bereft of treaties and we had criminals all over the place in Europe. When the Opposition was in government it did nothing about it. That is the indictment of the Opposition when it was in government. The Opposition has to accept that I am now having to grapple with this situation and I am trying to negotiate treaties with those countries that we recognise have a fair judicial system. But there is that barrier to extradition in that those countries are not entitled to carry out the death penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few minutes left to me I will deal with the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Flinders to amend clause 19. The amendment provides for people to be given copies of all documents at the time that they are arrested. I accept the principle of the amendment but I am advised that the amendment should be moved to clause 16 and I am prepared to move the same amendment to that clause. As a matter of fact, people who are arrested are given copies of all the documents now. We are merely putting in place in the Act something that already happens.

When we look at this whole argument about the problems that we are facing we see that they are not as alleged by the Opposition. I acknowledge the matters that have been mentioned, but the whole gamut of the debate has been on what is called the prima facie case. Normally in proceedings in this country, a prima facie case relates to the committal stage when people are given a chance to talk about whether there is a prima facie case, having heard witnesses for the prosecution, people having been subjected to cross-examination and the magistrate then being satisfied on the probabilities that there is a case to answer. The prima facie rule had never been used in extradition cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not have one approach for Australian citizens and another approach for foreigners?
—We are dealing here with the extradition of citizens from other countries.
—No, we are not; we are talking about extradition of our own.
—Yes, we are. We have said that, from our point of view, we will not extradite our citizens--
—You will not extradite our citizens?

—Unless other countries will allow the extradition of their citizens and, in most cases, they do not do that. We are prepared to try those people here for offences alleged to have been committed overseas. That is what this legislation states. So we do not have the problem that the honourable member thinks we have. The problem we have, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, is where somebody else's citizens who are here are the subject of extradition. It is a slight distinction but, nevertheless, it is a very major one.

SPEECH.PARA: I am trying to say to the Opposition that the amendment it has foreshadowed in respect of making copies of documents available is in order. The Opposition foreshadowed another amendment, to clause 21 in the following terms:
Clause 21, page 18, line 24, at the end of paragraph (d) add `unless the court otherwise orders'.

We cannot agree with that amendment because the court is limited as it is dealing with material that is before the magistrate. If we look at clause 21 we see that it deals with a review of magistrates' orders. The Opposition is talking about an appeal to a court. We see that clause 21 states:
. . . appeals to the High Court against an order made on that appeal; the following provisions have effect:
(d) the court to which the application or appeal is made shall have regard only to the material that was before the magistrate;

If the Opposition were to add `unless the court otherwise orders' it would mean that the court would have to look at some other matter that was not before the magistrate. In extradition cases we are dealing with matters that are limited in the sense of what can be put before the magistrate. We cannot go back and deal with the other issue--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 15-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 16 (Notice by Attorney-General).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 16, page 13, lines 11-13, omit subclause (3), substitute the following subclause:
``(3) As soon as practicable after the person is remanded under section 15 or the notice is issued, whichever is the later:
(a) a copy of the notice; and
(b) copies of the documents referred to in paragraph 19 (2) (a) and, if applicable, paragraph 19 (2) (b);
shall be given to the person.''.

I acknowledge that this is the same amendment that is proposed by the Opposition, which I accept. The only difference is that this amendment is to clause 16, as opposed to the Opposition's proposal to amend clause 19. These documents are already being given to people now and we are merely putting into statute form something that already operates in practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for acceeding to our proposal on this matter. It is a sensible proposal. I endorse the remarks that he has made and I thank him for his co-operation in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause 16, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 17 and 18-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 19 (Determination of eligibility for surrender).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 19, page 16, after subclause (4) insert the following subclauses:

``(4A) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, in the case of all extradition applications the magistrate shall determine whether the evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country satisfies the prima facie evidence test.
``(4B) For the purposes of subsection (4A), a reference to the prima facie evidence test being satisfied has the same meaning as in paragraph 11 (5) (b).

``(4C) In determining whether evidence satisfies the prima facie evidence test, the magistrate shall receive any evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country that would be admissible in criminal or extradition proceedings before the courts of the extradition country.
``(4D) For the purposes of subsection (4C), evidence may be admissible if it is provided by or on behalf of the extradition country in duly authenticated form.''.

This amendment relates to the matter of the prima facie rule. I must say that I am very sorry that the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) is not in the chamber as we had quite a discussion about the prima facie rule not so long ago. I wish to make a few comments in regard to some of the points made by the Attorney-General. The prima facie test is whether evidence adduced by the prosecutor, if uncontroverted, would be sufficient to put a person on trial. It is a screening test. We are not putting up a proposal that we have a trial in Australia and we then have a trial in the requesting country. That would simply defeat the purpose of extradition. We say that there ought to be a screening test. In fact, in regard to clause 45, as a result of the Government's proposal there is now an inconsistency and lack of symmetry, because the Government says that if somebody is sent overseas as a result of an extradition request, the prima facie rule is not needed and it will not operate, but if clause 45 is to operate and a trial is conducted in Australia, then in that situation the person has the benefit of the application of the prima facie rule. What is good in one case is not good in the other. It is an anomaly and I am surprised that we cannot seem to battle our way through it and to come up with a satisfactory response to this problem.

The Attorney-General kept talking about sworn evidence, but that is not a requirement under clause 19. The fact is that the Opposition says that there ought to be a screening process. The prima facie rule as we propose it would bring some consistency to the Government's legislation which we have before us today. The rationale for the decision taken hastily in 1985 was that we had to abolish the prima facie rule because the European and civil law countries had problems with the hearsay rule. I have heard the Attorney-General mention that fact on numerous occasions, and he said it again today. Our amendment brings the prima facie rule back into operation. The prima facie case may be proved on affidavit evidence. We do not suggest that witnesses should be flown to Australia to be available in such a hearing before a magistrate but, rather, we simply say that we recognise the problems that have arisen and, in putting back the prima facie rule as contained in our amendment, we meet those problems.

It is not a question of abrogating treaties. The reality is that, as I think the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said, in 1985 this Parliament took a decision that it should not have taken. This amendment very neatly meets the difficulties which gave rise to the 1985 proposal and, at the same time, it meets our requirements that the Australian system of justice should not fall into line willy-nilly because some of the civil law countries have had some difficulties in the past in the sense that they were not prepared or were not able to meet our evidentiary rules. Let us recognise that fact. I believe that the form of words contained in this amendment is innovative and constructive. I hope that, if the Government does not accept them today, in the weeks ahead the Attorney-General will have an opportunity to look further at it. We understand the problem that the Government has and that is why we have drafted the amendment in this manner. I think it is a solution. We have received very good advice on this matter from somebody who has provided advice to the Department in the past, so it is not advice that anybody can just cast to one side. I express the hope that the Government will look at our proposal in a constructive sort of way and I commend the amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great difficulty with clause 19 and, from experience, I oppose it. I believe that the Opposition is somewhat confused. I believe also that clause 19 is particularly dangerous in respect of citizens other than Australian citizens. Any person in this country should be entitled to the same level of protection as is afforded to Australian citizens, and I do not agree with honourable members opposite who have put a case that there is something sacrosanct about being an Australian citizen. If a system of justice is to be of any value, those standards must be applied universally and to all people. On that basis, foreigners in this country should have the exact same entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the case to which the Attorney-General has already referred, the Orionia case, the fact is that in those circumstances the Israelis asked for an extradition. When I objected on the ground of insufficient evidence, the Israelis then provided evidence to cover the grounds that I raised. When I raised a further objection, back came some more evidence. Every time evidence was received, it was self-serving evidence which would not have stood the test in court. The Attorney-General said that a court order was signed by an Israeli judge and that is true, but it was signed after the event. I do not see how a court order restraining a vessel from sailing but which was issued after the vessel had sailed can have any validity at all and it is beyond my comprehension how this can be the case.

I am aware also that a parallel of this concern is the case of an Australian citizen, Barry White, who I think was very unjustly treated by the Israelis. When I took this matter up with the Department of Foreign Affairs and said that in the matter the international law of the sea should have applied, the Department agreed with me, but it said that the international law is not recognised by the Israelis and that they were a law unto themselves. I very seriously question whether we should have an extradition treaty with a country which adopts these standards. I think that, in the general sense, what the Attorney-General is saying is right, but if people's liberties are allowed to be eroded at the corners, the whole system is threatened. Quite clearly, in this case there is a risk of injustice which has not been addressed simply because we have adopted this broad brush approach to these matters. I do not believe that is good enough. I am unable to support clause 19 as it stands and, therefore, I am afraid that I am bound to support the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was inte-rested to hear what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said because, if one is logical about the approach of equality before the law in Australia, when we come to clause 45 in a moment, one should say that that section, which gives jurisdiction to Australian courts to try Australian citizens for offences committed overseas, changes the balance and that that section should not give those Australian citizens that special protection that is referred to of allowing the Attorney-General to have those citizens tried in Australia. In the context of the debate on this clause, I will refer to something that the Attorney-General said in the second reading debate and I will ask him: Has he approved the extradition of any Australian citizens and, if he has, has he approved their extradition to countries that would not allow the extradition of their citizens to Australia in similar circumstances?
—Are you asking me personally?
—I am asking whether that has ever been done over the past five years.
—I will answer in a minute.

—I thank the Attorney-General for saying that he will do that, because I cannot help wondering, in the light of his earlier res-ponse in respect of the more general debate relating to the prima facie rule, which is linked into the question as to how it affects Australian citizens, whether in the case of clause 45 there should be an obligation for the trial in Australia of Australian citizens who have committed of-fences in countries which would not themselves extradite their own citizens to Australia in circumstances where the crime was of a similar nature, rather than leaving this matter to the Attorney-General's discretion. If the Government were to do that, it would alleviate some of my concern. If a country would not extradite its citizens to Australia, Australia should never extradite its citizens to that country; we should offer them trial in Australia. The question of the prima facie rule in regard to Australian citizens would be satisfied in a different way. At present, that clause leaves the situation open and discretionary, and I wonder whether amendments should be moved to appropriate clauses, such as clauses 22 or 45, to take away the existing discretion and provide that the only countries to which Australia will extradite Australian citizens will be those which will agree to reciprocity of arrangements in respect of their citizens, otherwise we would be putting Australian citizens at a relative disadvantage because we would not be making it mandatory that clause 45 be applied to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have limited time in which to deal with three matters. In answer to my colleague from Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), I make the point that there is an order by the court in Beersheba-and I know there is a contest about it-following a decision by Mr Justice Gilardi who determined the ownership of a certain vessel. The charge is one of theft and stealing, not disobeying a court injunction. We face the problem that there is what we call prima facie evidence of the highest calibre in terms of the court having not only determined what had happened but also ownership. I know that that is in dispute, but the fact is that that is of some significance when the Government of Israel asks for these citizens to be sent back when they are not Australian citizens. This takes up the matters raised by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson); if those people were Australian citizens, because the Israeli nation does not extradite its citizens, we would be able to deal with these people here on that basis with a discretion. That is what we are talking about. If we were not able to obtain the evidence that is required to satisfy our laws in prosecution, I have a discretion not to do that. If we could not get the evidence and we could not get the witnesses, we would not do it. That is the reason for the discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter to which I refer-from what the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said, it is most important, and I hope that what I am about to say will mean that he will not pursue his amendment-is that at present the Criminal Justice Bill is before the United Kingdom Parliament. It removes the requirement that foreign countries provide prima facie evidence in support of extradition requests. The United Kingdom has abandoned that principle. We do not want to go back to what the United Kingdom will abandon. I trust, having said that, that that will be the answer. That was obviously to be the position following the Harare conference. The British were one out. I acknowledge that the Canadians are thinking of doing something, but they are the only ones who are thinking along those lines, and legislation before the British Parliament will remove the requirement, the reason being that the British have not been able to negotiate any extradition treaties with Europe. No European country has been able to extradite anyone from Britain for more than 40 years, and so there is a complete impasse.

We all know that, with modern criminal activity, it is important to talk about not only extradition of people but also forfeiture of assets. We must have the ability to recognise that, if there is a conviction in one country, assets can be forfeited because of that conviction. The Swiss in particular are entering into treaties with Australia on that very basis. It helps us no end, because a number of Australian criminals have been prepared to put their assets into Swiss bank accounts. We can say, `If we get a conviction, the Swiss will be able to do something about it'. Therefore, the world is working in unison in dealing with criminal conduct. May I say, with some sense of modesty, that since I have held this portfolio Australia has signed, or is about to sign, about 20 extradition treaties, with a further 16 being subject to negotiation. There is an enormous gap in our position when we consider the likes of the people we have had to get back from countries in Europe, and when we look at the assets we are confiscating. It is a very simple solution to a modern problem which arises because of the rapidity of travel on aircraft. People who are usually pretty sharp at evading the law do not stay in one place for long enough so that they can be dealt with. Therefore, we are chasing many people at the same time, as are other countries.

The problem with the Opposition's amendment-even if we agreed with it, which we do not-is that proposed clause 19 (4c) would require proof of the evidentiary laws of the requesting country in the Australian courts. Every time a court sought to adduce evidence, there would have to be strict proof of the foreign law relating to that evidence. The proposal would result in extreme costs and cumbersome procedures which would be of no real assistance to the fugitive. I make the point: If we have a request from the country concerned and if we are prepared to trust that country's legal system, I believe we ought to be prepared to trust that country's government's request when it not only makes a request but also gives a statement of the nature of the offence and some details of it. In other words, we must know whether a crime has been committed and, if so, what are the particulars. For that reason, we could not accept the amendment.

The Opposition ought to rethink the situation. Honourable members opposite are asking me to rethink it, and I ask them to rethink it now in view of the fact that before the British Parliament is a Bill that will do the very thing we are doing here. I have no doubt that, if that is the situation, the Canadians will also rethink the situation. It is a waste of time if there is no comity in relation to uniform procedures for extradition of nationals from countries.

I appreciate the concept put forward by the Opposition. Honourable members feel that there is a gap and that a mistake has been made, but I assure them that that is not the case. When I was in Harare arguing the position with the Commonwealth countries, I learnt that every one of them, except Britain and now perhaps Canada, was prepared to enter into bilateral arrangements. We were taking comfort from the fact that, although we did not have treaties with one another, we had the Commonwealth arrangement, and therefore a treaty was not necessary. If we were obliged to apply the old British standard of prima facie rule, it would be better to get away from that and negotiate bilateral arrangements with all Commonwealth countries. We could do that tomorrow.

I believe that the simplest approach, which I proposed in Harare, is that Commonwealth countries agree to a standard that will apply to all of them. I believe it is coming to that now if the British give in. Britain was the only country that could not see its way clear at that time. If that is the position, there is no purpose in this amendment. It gives no greater protection to the fugitive. Really, it is a bit insulting to the country with which Australia has a treaty to suggest that, because that country has made a request, that is not good enough and we want to talk about sworn evidence. Further, under the proposed amendments, that sworn evidence will have to be tested by our magistrates as to whether it would be admissible as evidence in Australia. Never at any stage have we had the benefit of people giving evidence in the normal prima facie sense; there has merely been a requirement by the British that there be sworn evidence before certain people before that evidence is admitted. That facility was not available in the civil law countries; that was not the way they did it. Therefore, there was a complete gap and nothing was done for 40 years. The British have been on their own, and that is a delightful way to be, but the desired situation in relation to extradition was not achieved.

Having said that, the Government could not now go back on something which we have been quite convinced was the only way we would ever be able to negotiate extradition treaties. We would be throwing them right out because we would be putting tests in there as to what sort of evidence we think ought to be admitted. I ask the House to bear in mind that the concept has gone away from the strict proof and credibility of witnesses. It would basically be in forms and procedure as to whether there was some sworn evidence before a judge. I make the point strongly that I do not think it in any way lessens the requirement that there be a statement from a government with which we have a treaty that an offence allegedly has been committed. We accept the principles of the treaty that if the person is sent back to that country they will be dealt with in accordance with the principles of justice which we think are fair and reasonable. We do not have treaties with countries that do not have such a system. I am delighted to see that the British, after all this time, have recognised the position. It is very clear, now that we are in the international world, that we have this particular ability to negotiate treaties. We do it on the basis that a government is democratic and has a judicial system that allows prosecution but requires strict proof of guilt. That is the normal thing.

The honourable member for Sturt asked me whether there was anybody who had ever been sent back to a country by way of extradition. I was involved with one case. It involved an alleged Australian citizen who had obtained nationality but who held dual nationality. He left this country and had gone back to the country where he was born. He, therefore, had a nationality that that country recognised. In other words, it did not recognise the Australian nationality which he had obtained some years before. He basically lived in that country for a long time after obtaining Australian nationality. He lived in Australia for only a short time. For some reason he was always able to renew his passport which shows that we are not always as good as we should be in terms of applying the law. He was not here but he kept renewing his passport in the other country where he was living with his family. He was employed there. The charge was that he had misappropriated a substantial sum of money from his employer. He flew over here rapidly and so he was sent back on the basis that he was not prepared to accept Australian nationality. He was living and working in that country and just renewing a passport. There was only one case in which that happened. We did not think there was an injustice in that position. That is the only case of which I am aware. For the reasons I have mentioned I am not prepared to accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up some of the points that the Attorney-General has made on this matter. Obviously, I am not surprised that he will not consent to our amendment. I appreciate the history of this matter. Our suggestion for a review, a rethink, is still well based and well founded. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), you, Mr Deputy Chairman, and I have put up today a very substantial case which has been well prepared. The Attorney talks about what the British have done. I have not seen the Bill of which he speaks. He tells me that it is a Bill, so obviously it has not gone through.
—It is there.

—He says that it is there. I am not aware of it. I was told that the British entered into an agreement, treaty or protocol-or whatever it was-with some of its European neighbours and by doing so abandoned, as I understand it, the prima facie rule. Of interest is the fact that we would not similarly accede to that treaty or protocol for the reason that we were not happy with some of the other signatories. It is no good just saying that if the Brits did it it is okay. I understand that the Attorney is looking for some uniformity in these things. I understand that but I do not think that the argument per se carries--
—It is your argument.

—No. Our argument was not spec- ifically what do the Brits do or not do; it was that we have had 140-odd years of common law tradition and we should not just throw it out the window as we did in 1985 without having a decent debate about it. If the Attorney wants to criticise us for coming back a second time to rehash it, we are prepared to accept that criticism. The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said that the legislation was rushed through and that it is an indictment on everybody in the Parliament that these things happen. But that is not to say that in the end we should not sit down to debate it properly. That is what we are doing today. The Attorney can throw criticisms at us but I do not accept them. There is a lot of talk about consistency-do what they do and do what they say-but the reality is, as I pointed out a moment ago, that clause 45 provides that those people, for whom jurisdiction is created in Australia and for whom there can be a trial, get the benefit of our system with the prima facie rule and all, but if we are sending somebody overseas they do not get it. I want the Attorney to explain to me how it is that he reconciles that inconsistency. I just cannot see it. As to whether it is insulting to some of these foreign countries it is just not a question of whether it is an insult or whether it is not. The question is: What are the standards of justice that we believe ought to apply in Australia? That is what the issue is about. So the red herring about insulting people is irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney talked about the matter of sworn evidence. The reality is that under clause 19 there is no question of any evidence--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there is.

—No. What we need is a warrant and a description of the offence. That is it, and off people will go willy nilly. All we say is that there ought to be a screening test because that is the Australian way of doing things. Because of difficulties, which we acknowledge and which we have met in this amendment, why should we effectively lower and change our standards? It is a reasonable proposition. I hope that the Attorney is not so wedded to the decision that was rushed through in 1985 that he is not prepared to stop and think about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General for responding to that question. In a way his answer raises as many, if not more, problems than it solves. In the case the Attorney instanced, the facts as described by him, on the surface, clearly warrant the sort of decision that was taken. But it raises a problem for the many dual citizens that we have in this country. In the case in point there was a question mark over the Australian citizenship either because of the way it was gained or because of its reality because there was not a long period of time establishing links with Australia. There are many dual citizens of Australia and of other countries who have their permanent homes here in Australia but who have largely lost connection with those other countries except for the fact that they were their country of birth. That perhaps is a matter for another debate. It relates to a view I have expressed in this chamber before about how we should try to negotiate more sensible arrangements with countries that today do not recognise that their citizens have gained Australian citizenship. We recognise their continuing links with the countries of their birth.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to clause 19, I strongly support the proposal of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I would like to think that when we come to clause 22 the Attorney will give his apparent commitment-I do not know how he will handle in future dual citizenship cases-to the question of a discretion which is different from the one he described in his response to me about whether the trial goes ahead. That depends on whether there is evidence that can be adduced in Australia to enable the trial to be effectively proceeded with. There is another discretion-that is, whether the Australian citizen will be extradited. I would like to see that discretion taken away. At present clause 22 reads:
For the purposes of sub-section (2), the eligible person is only to be surrendered in relation to a qualifying extradition offence if . . .

There are several provisos., I think an additional proviso should be included in the following terms: `If the Attorney-General is satisfied that the country requesting the extradition of an Australian citizen would in similar circumstances permit the extradition to Australia of its citizens'. It would then be quite clear that if an Australian commits an offence in another country, has returned to Australia and is apprehended in Australia, that Australian citizen will be dealt with for that offence under Australian law and have the protections under Australian law of all the prima facie requirements, not as to whether that person is sent overseas to a hostile legal environment but as to whether the case proceeds ultimately to trial. I know that that is moving closer to the civil law situation, but I do not believe that we should surrender Australian citizens to countries which are not prepared to surrender their citizens in similar circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes remaining before the debate is interrupted, I will answer the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). We will not surrender our citizens to countries that will not surrender theirs. Such a matter is the subject of a treaty, and the discretion lies in that treaty. It is not done, so there is no problem about that matter. That is the whole point of being able to say that if an offence has been committed, we can deal with that offence rather than face the issue that the honourable member is worried about-that we might be subject to an extradition request and that we could not make one against the citizens of that country. It will be done on an equal basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point is that if the Opposition were to apply the test that it now wants to apply in clause 19-it wants the magistrate here to be satisfied as to the prima facie evidence, and also that the evidence be admissible in Australia-it would negate the treaties that we already have and which accept this point. This is different from what the Opposition is demanding. With the greatest respect, why should we abandon what the common law position was and what the British have always been able to insist on? I tell honourable members opposite-I think without contradiction-that Britain has failed in terms of being able to get extraditions. That is why it is altering its law. But the Opposition still wants something included, other than what we can negotiate with other countries for which we have the greatest of respect and whose principles of justice we accept.

There will not be some outrageous request whereby, for some ulterior motive, somebody will be asked to come back to another country to be dealt with. We would not have a treaty with that sort of country; that is the position. We accept the fact that when the country makes a request, it does so on the basis of pretty good sworn evidence. It is not much good our standing here today, saying, `All they will do is send in a bit of paper'. It will not come from a person; it will come from the nation itself with which we have the treaty. There will be a statement of the offence that applies in the other country, and particulars of the offence. The Opposition says, `We still want to test whether that statement was properly sworn on an affidavit before a judge and whether it is the sort of evidence that will be admitted here'. One will never be able to go to the trial situation. The issue is a request to return a citizen of the other country-not of ours-to be dealt with in accordance with that country's law in respect of something that allegedly happened in that country. It is a mere accident that the person happens to be here. Usually the person is on the run.

Not one Opposition member has put up one case of a request for extradition that did not have that sort of bona fide aspect to it. For those reasons, and because my time has almost expired, I want to assure honourable members that if there were any suggestion of injustice we would certainly look into it. But not one Opposition member has mentioned any. Now the British are abandoning their old position, which was outmoded and irrelevant, and which prevented anything being done by way of extradition. I invite honourable members opposite to have a look at what the British are adopting and see whether it is not what we are now doing.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the extent of so-called deregulation of coal export controls? Has there been a deterioration in prices as a result of this so-called deregulation? What would be the likely effects on the Australian coal industry if all export controls were to be abolished?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we all know, the honourable member takes a lot of interest in the coal industry, particularly in the western district of New South Wales. He at least got a better reception in Lithgow yesterday than Mr Greiner, the Leader of the New South Wales Opposition. If deregulation is a reference to the relaxation of export controls on coal announced in September 1986, it needs to be emphasised that the decision did not involve the removal of controls. The former Minister for Trade, my colleague who is now the Minister for Education, Employment and Training, Mr Dawkins, used the export control powers late last year and again early this year to reject a number of settlements judged to be contrary to the national interest. In recent months the Government has refused to approve a number of settlements which had the potential to contribute to further erosion in prices. While export controls can be effective in curtailing unjustified undercutting of prices by competing Australian suppliers and the creation of new low price markers, the general level of prices in our export markets is determined by international supply and demand. If one looks at the industry's recent export performance over the past 12 months and tries to discern the underlying effects of the relaxation of export controls, one finds that this reveals a situation very much as anticipated at the time that the Government was considering its decision. Frankly, it is too early to assess the long term impact of the decision, although it is important that we recognise that there is a risk that excessive resort to the controls could damage Australia's deserved reputation as a reliable source of supply.

ANSWER.PARA: The international market-place cannot be manipulated, especially in a buyer's market with so much excess capacity and intense competition, and it would be counterproductive for Australia to seek prices above the market. It would result only in lost tonnages and lost jobs. The latest market indicators, honourable members will be pleased to know, show that immediate price prospects are improving. Prices have already risen a little in the American and European markets, and most of our competitors are having to ask for higher prices to cover significant cost increases. The fact is that our industry cannot be squeezed any further, and the implications of this squeeze are becoming clear to our own customers. I was able to reinforce that in Japan last month, having already indicated the determination to underscore the importance to Australia of a viable coal industry, and having let it be known that scrutiny of applications for export permits in accordance with the guidelines accepted by the Australian Coal Consultative Council has been intensified, as has the monitoring of shipments under approved permits. This is not bluff or bluster. The industry and our customers understand it, and many of them have welcomed it, and they understand it in Japan as well. Where there is a situation, as there is in the electorate of the honourable member for Calare, in the western district of New South Wales, where there have been concessions by the work force, where there is high investment in mines and the mines are highly productive, and where the risk of closure leads to sterilisation of coal reserves, people understand the need for the Government to take the national interest into account.

I should also note, in concluding, that the Government has no intention of reverting to the old system of prior approval of price parameters. Equally, it has no intention of abolishing controls altogether, as suggested by the Leader of the National Party of Australia lately. As noted, the present system of controls, given adequate resources, can be effective in overriding settlements likely to set harmful precedents for ongoing negotiations and can, in the meantime, give the degree of price protection so desperately needed to ensure the viability of the industry.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The suggestion that I could not answer the question yesterday is probably not correct, but I am pleased to tell the House that last night in Paris the World Heritage Committee approved the inscription of Uluru-Ayers Rock-Mount Olga National Park on the World Heritage List. That approval occurred, despite the best efforts of the responsible Northern Territory Minister, uninvited and unwanted, who spent many tens of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money in Paris trying to influence this body of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation not to admit the Uluru National Park to the World Heritage List.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that most Australians with any compassion and any feeling for this country would share my view-and that might well leave out all those characters opposite, but then again they have been known as environmental vandals and people with very little feeling for the heritage of Australia, so that does not surprise me. The nomination, of course, was suggested by the traditional owners, for whom many features of the national park hold special significance. Indeed, the Rock itself and all the other features of the park are treasured by all Australians, but particularly by the traditional Aboriginal owners. The listing will not interfere with the rights of traditional owners or visitors; in fact, it honours the area and gives a special responsibility to manage the area in co-operation with the traditional owners in a fitting and proper manner.

I might make the observation in passing, as I did yesterday, that the responsibility for this area is the responsibility of this Australian Government and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, not the responsibility, fortunately, of the Northern Territory Government. The World Heritage Committee commended the initiatives taken by the Australian Government in its administration of the park through the National Parks and Wildlife Service. I note that the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is sitting in the House today, and I am sure he is delighted about that. The World Heritage Committee also praised the way in which the traditional owners were involved in the planning, decision-making and administration of the national park, and I guess that the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs must also feel great satisfaction about that. He was very much part of it. Of course, that great tradition has been carried on by his successor. The Committee also made special mention of the efforts to reintroduce species which had formerly lived in the park but which had died out since European settlement. The Committee encouraged Australia to persist with such a program. Those species-for the elucidation of you vandals on the other side-included the rufous hare-wallaby, the burrowing bethong, the brushtail possum, the bilby, and the ghost bat-and I do not know the Latin for those generic descriptions. The Committee also expressed the hope that a larger area of central Australia might eventually be considered for addition to the listed property, and that is something which this Government, of course, would support.

I should add that stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park is also being considered for inscription on the World Heritage List and, despite the fact that the Northern Territory Government is working as hard as it can to prevent that with a campaign of misinformation and mischief, I am pretty sure that eventually our efforts to have stage 2 included will reap rewards. I think that all honourable members of the House should be pleased that this unique part of Australia, this very fragile environment of the Uluru National Park, has been recognised by the UNESCO World Heritage Committee as fit for inscription and I hope that it will not be too long before stage 2 is included.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to prudential statement No. 15 released by the Reserve Bank of Australia on 29 January this year in which the Reserve Bank:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . asked each bank to give it prior notification of the bank's intention to enter into an exceptionally large exposure to an individual client or group of related clients. It has indicated that in such cases a bank should be able to show that the proposed exposure would not result in it undertaking an excessive risk.

I ask the Treasurer whether the Reserve Bank was notified prior to 20 October of the reported large exposures of some Australian banks which had advanced unsecured loans to certain companies currently experiencing difficulties. Has the Treasurer been involved in discussions with his Department and the Reserve Bank concerning the exposure of certain banks to these clients following the stock market collapse?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is broadly yes. Given that we have seen in the last few years fairly substantial takeovers within Australian commerce, and the size of the fundings, this could under some circumstances impact upon the shareholders' funds of the institutions concerned. The Reserve Bank has asked the institutions covering its field of operation to advise it of such arrangements. Having said that, there is still sitting behind any special requests by the Reserve Bank the formal prudential structure and asset ratios which are observed by the Australian banks. It is possible for a bank still to observe that ratio but lend against a particular transaction more than one might prudently do against the shareholders' funds and expose the shareholders' funds to any shift in the fortunes of a particular corporation. The bank generally keeps an intelligent interest in all these issues. In the wake of the stock market crash it asked the major banks to let it know what financing arrangements the corporations may seek to put into place and what exposure that would have on banks' shareholders' funds and prudential ratios, et cetera. As far as I know, that is still in place and the banks are willingly letting the Governor and his staff know what those particular transactions are. I add that the Government regards it as being very important in the wake of the stock market crash to keep the financial system liquid and to provide the right climate and the time for some of these large holdings to be rationalised. That has been taking place. We see reports of that in the papers daily.
—What does `rationalised' mean?
—The honourable member ought to know what `rationalised' means.
—Order! I inform the honourable member for Deakin that no supplementary questions are allowed.
—If the honourable member does not know what that means now he is in more trouble than I thought he was.
—He has ducked away.
—Well, I think I will leave it at that.

—Is the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs aware of allegations made in today's Melbourne Press that community youth support scheme (CYSS) offices have been shut down without notice, and suggestions by some project officers that such actions were taken without justification? Is there any truth in these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. There is no truth in the allegations. What is true is that, as honourable members will be aware, on 31 October 1987 I indicated to all honourable members that we were approving funding for some 332 CYSS projects throughout Australia. That included funding for a new project in Reservoir. It also involved the closure of three projects at Mount Druitt in New South Wales, Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory and Moranbah in Queensland. The funding of some 18 projects that were going through serious operational difficulties was continued until 30 November 1987. There was to be a reassessment of their commitment and capacity to perform at an acceptable standard in accordance with CYSS guidelines. Following the reassessment of these 18 projects, I approved continued funding of 12 projects until 31 October 1988 because I was satisfied that they indicated the intention to comply with the guidelines and accept responsibility for the training of the young unemployed. I approved three months funding only for three projects: Parramatta in New South Wales, Alamein in Victoria and Chigwell in Tasmania. Although they indicated a willingness to comply, they needed more time to implement their changes.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of Collingwood, Elwood and Gympie, I discontinued funding because it was perfectly clear from their record that there was an inability to comply with CYSS guidelines. Very simply, the Government wants to make it perfectly clear that there needs to be a commitment and a responsibility from all CYSS projects to undertake and be responsible for retraining and assistance to young unemployed people to enable them to enter the labour market. Some CYSS projects believe that they are at liberty to determine their own course and pursue courses which clearly have no impact in getting young unemployed people into the labour market. It is no fun for me as Minister to close a CYSS project, particularly in an electorate such as Melbourne, and even more particularly in an electorate such as Melbourne Ports, but it is important that it be understood that CYSS projects have a heavy responsibility and an important role to play as the Government continues its employment and training programs. They should be able to discharge their responsibility.

Many projects that are doing exceptionally well need additional funding. We will not allow a situation to continue whereby some CYSS projects which are receiving quite considerable sums of money are not capable and willing to discharge their obligations. In that situation, unfortunately, I am prepared to indicate that I will terminate those projects.

—It only lost $33m.

—I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to concerns expressed by consultant physicians and some patient groups about the changes made to the fee schedule in the May economic statement. Can the Minister advise the House of the outcome of discussions with the consultant physicians and what action the Government intends to take to resolve these concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated to the House on prior occasions, over the last few months there have been extensive consultations between representatives of my Department and the Australian Association of Consultant Physicians. These discussions culminated last week in a meeting between me, representatives of the Australian Association of Consultant Physicians, the Royal Australian College of Physicians and the Australian Medical Association (AMA). At that meeting certain principles were recognised. The first was that consultant physicians have an ongoing management role for certain patients with certain serious, acute or chronic complex conditions. The second was that ongoing consultations for patients with chronic illnesses are not necessarily easier nor less demanding in time. The third was that consultations following the initial consultation will at times be of lesser complexity than the usual follow-up consultations and that this should be reflected in the medical benefits schedule. The final one was that consultant physicians should maintain an ongoing dialogue with the Department of Community Services and Health to address issues of concern to physicians, to patients and to the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am hopeful that the revised arrangements arising from that meeting can be implemented before Christmas but the timing will be subject to the completion of necessary legal and administrative processes. The new arrangements will remove item 118 from the schedule and introduce a new fee structure for consultant physicians based on an initial consultation, a conventional consultation and a minor follow-up consultation. The Australian Association of Consultant Physicians will encourage physicians to charge a minor consultation fee where appropriate and the Royal Australian College of Physicians has undertaken to support in principle the introduction of the new fee structure.

In addition, there will be continuing discussions between the profession and my Department regarding procedures for referral of patients to consultant physicians. These discussions will necessarily involve both the AMA and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. Discussion will also cover particular areas of concern to the Government in respect of consultant physician practice, particular concerns by the physicians themselves about the valuation of consultations and the monitoring of the new fee structure on consultant physician practice. Under the revised arrangements the rebate for the new minor consultation item will be the same as for item 118 that it replaces. Within this structure I believe that the budgetary objectives of the Government and the professional concerns of the consultant physicians have been met in a way that ensures that patients should not be faced with excessive out-of-pocket costs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMPENSATION CLAIMS BY HMAS VOYAGER SURVIVORS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the scathing comments of Mr Justice O'Bryan of the Victorian Supreme Court when he criticised the Government for hiding behind the statute of limitations in its defence against claims by HMAS Voyager survivors. In particular, I refer the Attorney-General to Mr Justice O'Bryan's statement: `This ruling is most unfortunate and reflects poorly upon the conduct of the defendant'. This relates to 100 Voyager survivors, in case Government members are interested. I ask the Attorney-General: Why has the Government used this defence when it has previously stated that it would not do so? Has the Government not already admitted liability in this matter? Why is natural justice in the courts being denied to these claimants? Does the Government realise that these Voyager claimants, and all Defence Force personnel, put their lives at risk for the nation? Does the Government understand the implications of this decision? In the name of common justice, will the Minister undertake to have this decision reversed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leaving out the dramatics, let me make very clear that justice has always been applied in respect of the Voyager case. The honourable gentleman would be the first to admit that the accident happened 23 years ago. There happens to be a legal principle that if one delays making a claim one can place the defendant at a disadvantage.
—Yes, but that has never been the suggestion.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will cease interjecting.
—It ought to be recognised that a number of people were injured and a number of people died, and that was back in February 1964.
—All the facts are known.
—The facts are known and, of course, compensation was awarded to a large number of people at that time. It is also fact that--
—But there were a number of cases--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for North Sydney. The honourable member knows he is out of order.
—That is very unfair.
—The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting also.

—It is worth while listening to my answer without the interjections. There were 292 claims settled at that time. The honourable gentleman might ask himself the question: Why is it that all of a sudden after 23 years we are now faced with some 100 claims for psychiatric disorders? The honourable gentleman might also ask: How is it that all of a sudden 100 people have decided to make claims? The issue relates to legal principles that now apply. No claim has ever been rejected on the basis of merit but, as Opposition members know, the statute of limitations has been applied by all previous Attorneys-General in all cases. In these sorts of cases we are entitled to plead the issue. Obviously, it hurts the Opposition to have to face up to the fact because it can be a good political gimmick to get on to the tragedy of 1964 and ask the Government, `Why aren't you doing something now?'. We in turn could say to the Opposition, `Why didn't you do something then?'. That should be the issue. Let us cut out all this nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: Also, the Opposition ought to acknowledge that these people are not denied the normal Commonwealth employees compensation. Apparently the Opposition forgets that but it is still their entitlement. The Opposition does not recognise that their claim is on the basis of negligence. It is all very well for a justice of the Victorian Supreme Court to say now that there is some problem. This same issue was also discussed earlier before Master Brett when he gave leave to amend the defence and it was also upheld by the Full Court of Victoria, which made no castigations of the Government in this issue. It is about time that the Opposition looked at the issue. If the 100 people who have now decided to make a claim could convince that court that there is merit in their claim we could then talk about setting aside the statute of limitations. One would expect that a claim would be made within a reasonable period. The Opposition must look at the fact that after 23 years all of a sudden 100 claims are made. Is it not a fact-I will put this right to the honourable gentleman-that a firm of lawyers in Melbourne decided that it might be an opportunity to ginger up a bit of business?

I make it very clear: nobody denies justice to servicemen. They are entitled to make their claim in the terms of workers compensation or Commonwealth employees compensation. Many of them have been in many other occupations since they left the Navy; they have not been in the Navy all that time. If one has a look at their records one will see that they have been in an infinite number of occupations where they well might have suffered the disability of a psychiatric disturbance. Our position is certainly not without precedent. My predecessors, from Barwick down anyway, have always said that the statute of limitations should apply where the defendant would be placed at a disadvantage-in fact did not have any evidence to refute what had been said because of the lapse of time, witnesses having died and the whole set of circumstances having changed. It is all very well to say that we must not take that view on the Voyager incident. We all know that was a tragic incident. We all know, though, that a number of people were compensated. The question I ask is: Why did it take these people 23 years to make a claim on the basis of a psychiatric problem, not a physical injury? On that basis we have to deal with this issue in accordance with precedent because otherwise--

TALK.START.PARA: —You admitted liability.

—We did not admit liability. That is not the point. There was no case. It went to the Department. It did not come to the Government. On that basis, it is interesting to know that when the Department apparently made an admission of liability, all of a sudden, after 23 years, 100 further claims are made. Were they made on the basis of merit or on the basis of the precedent that an easy way to get a bit of money was to make a claim? That is the point. I want to make it clear that those who suffered injury are entitled to compensation. This is not a claim for compensation. This is a claim for damages. That is the distinction.
—Ha, ha!
—The honourable gentleman may laugh--
—Order! Just ignore the interventions.

—That is why there was a lapse of 23 years, because they would have been compensated before this in the normal employees compensation field, which is still open to them. There is no statute of limitations applying there. It is simply because some intelligent lawyer decided that there was a good chance of running a few cases. Not only that, but I have correspondence from people saying, `Look, isn't this a bit unusual, Mr Attorney-General? My neighbour, who was formerly in the Navy, was working very hard recently. Suddenly, he got a letter from a solicitor suggesting that he stop work and make a claim because there is a chance of getting some money'. That is the issue, and these are the problems. Those claims can always be dealt with on the basis of workers' compensation but, from the point of view of damage from a breach of care, we are entitled to plead the statute of limitations. Barwick pleaded it, Bowen pleaded it, Snedden pleaded it, Durack pleaded it: so why is the Opposition suddenly saying that we should make a special exception because it was the Voyager disaster, and only in the Voyager disaster will we not plead the statute of limitations? That statute has been pleaded right across the board, irrespective of government, for the simple reason that, because there has been a gap of 23 years, the defendant cannot find the evidence and cannot refute the issue.
—But why are war crimes different?
—If the right honourable gentleman wanted to debate the war crimes issue, he should have done it when the Bill concerning them was before the House.

ANSWER.PARA: We want to know why, after 23 years, there is a rash of claims from virtually one source. People saw the solicitor saying on television what a dramatic thing it is to think that the Government is being so heartless and has refused this claim. What a coincidence it is that, after 23 years, 100 people suddenly decide to make a claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the House. Can the Minister tell the House whether the Government's program will be finished by tomorrow evening?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. A lot of members on both sides of the House have been asking me whether our program will be completed tomorrow. This has been a very interesting year. We obviously would have been finishing Parliament a little earlier but for the disruption caused by the Opposition in the middle part of the year when it continually challenged us to an election. It was not our view that the election should have been held in mid-year. We thought that we should run the full term. However, the Opposition was disrupting matters and challenging us every day here in Parliament. Finally, the Prime Minister succumbed. I advised him against it, but he did so, and that has disrupted the program. It has presented us with other problems, because the Labor Government members now take up two-thirds of the seats. We have never experienced that previously.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been lots of other changes. We actually have a member for Wentworth who stays awake during Question Time and, by the look of the benches usually occupied by the National Party of Australia, that Party thinks that the program is finished already. Certainly, the Agent-General has gone. We look forward to the judgment that will be made by the Leader of the Opposition when he announces his shadow Ministry. They are all on trial and there will be changes. I notice that some people are trying to keep their places by saying a lot, and others by saying nothing. If the honourable member for Bass continues his way up the ladder by saying nothing, he could finish up as Leader of the Opposition. He has made more progress than Marcel Marceau. The honourable member for Menzies has had a good session. He has been pulled in by the Opposition on a number of occasions when it has required somebody who has a little bit of fluency and skill in debating, so he might be attracted back into the membership of the shadow Ministry. The honourable member for Goldstein does not seem to be attracting that much support.

We have finished the year without Joh, in spite of all the promises that he was going to come down and lead the nation. Joh is back on the farm and now we are waiting for rolling Stone. He will take Tom's seat and come down and take Ian's position as Leader of the National Party. Then he will put forward his views that we should live in the world of John Stones. It would be an interesting world to live in.

But I assure honourable members who have made their arrangements to go to pensioner parties, high school speeches, farming their electorates, back-slapping and shaking hands, that we shall be finishing tomorrow night.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order and Safety: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And, your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr John Brown,Mr Cobb,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Halverson,Mr Hicks,Mr Langmore,Mr MacKellar,Mr Ian Robinson and Mrs Sullivan.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food, irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Tim Fischer,Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set NO penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set NO penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and END the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98 per cent of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Ronald Edwards,Mr Rocher and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Cowan and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb and Dr Harry Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Lyne Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement on civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card

That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal;
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
