PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card

The Tax will:

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The Post Office serves a community need and we should be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free Zones

The petition of the undersigned express concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

It will affect the enrolment of children at preschool next year, with a likely outcome being the closure of some ACT preschools. It will also affect the voluntary financial commitment parents already make to preschools, without which they could not function on a day to day basis. We believe that preschools are very cost effective in respect to their multi faceted role in educational, social, health, emotional and physical development. We envisage the long term effects of the fee to be a reduction in the quality and frequency of preschooling with the preschool sector degenerating into a user pays system for those who can afford it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate policy action to reduce the vulnerability of Australia in light of our huge foreign debt.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance has the succinct remark that the Australian economy is, by any yardstick, in bad shape. One ought not to believe the myth that is peddled by the Hawke-Keating Government that because we are primarily a raw commodity producer our predicament can be blamed on other countries-it cannot. It is time to face the facts. The vulnerability of our economy is due largely to our huge and growing debt burden.
—The Treasurer is not even here!

—No. The person who is significantly responsible for the situation we face is not even here today. The huge Budget deficits brought down by this current Treasurer in 1983-84 swallowed our domestic savings and forced us as a nation to borrow overseas. Our net foreign debt has virtually quadrupled from 1983 to 1987. Australia's net foreign debt now stands at over 30 per cent of our gross domestic product; that is, in net terms, about $5,000 for each Australian resident. Dare I mention that for honourable members in this chamber alone that amounts to about $750,000? How does that make them feel? Many Australians who are listening to this debate are in an infinitely worse position to cope with this than honourable members of this chamber, other than a few who are fast and loose with their money on the other side of this House. It was during this period that our AAA international credit rating was downgraded for the first time in our history-a great legacy for the nation. We continue to run huge current account deficits, adding about $1m to our debt every month.

SPEECH.PARA: The balance of payments figures for October show that the deficit on goods and services was almost $2 billion for the first four months of 1987-88. In other words, Australia continues to borrow just to pay the interest on our debt. This great nation is borrowing more and more each month simply to pay the interest on our debt. According to the latest statistics, these interest payments amount to nearly 23 per cent of our export income. Clearly that is an unsustainable state of affairs. Moreover, it is not as if it is our only problem. We have been plagued in recent years under this Government by large Budget deficits-both Commonwealth and State; high rates of wage and price inflation; high unemployment-particularly youth unemployment which is continuing steady at in excess of 20 per cent; abysmal productivity; and poor investment performance. The underlying basis of our economy remains undeniably very weak indeed. Yet this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) maintains that the economy is on track. On track to where? Buenos Aires, bananaland or Argentina? The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in the Senate told us where it was on track to-to Argentina. Those opposite sit there smugly not worrying about the sufferings of ordinary Australians or on what they are compiling for this nation month after month.

The past policies of the Government to date have just not equipped us to cope well with the current external pressures. We were arguing before, during and after the Budget that was brought down this year, well in advance of the stock market collapse, that the Government was placing this nation in the most vulnerable position and that unless it forced the pace of adjustment in the face of those external difficulties it was sailing far too close to the margin in case anything happened internationally. We were talking particularly about any drop in terms of trade. However, since then we have had the massive drop on the stock market. We made these calls well before the collapse on world stock markets. So clearly there is even more pressing need for tougher policies.

The Government's complacency is now drifting beyond simply that complacency that flows from the arrogance that pervades this Government. It is drifting into negligence-outright breaches of duty of care by this Government to the Australian people. The Government's refusal to take the necessary steps to force the pace of adjustment is imposing huge social costs, largely in terms of additional debt and forgone opportunities for work and investment, costs that are largely borne by ordinary Australians, costs that could be avoided if the Government had the courage to act now. The postponement of expenditure cuts only adds to the uncertainty faced by all Australians and unquestionably threatens investor confidence further. Moreover, as I think is being increasingly comprehended, the uncertain economic environment tends to breed financial instability. Indeed, recent reports in the Press concerning large unsecured loans from the banks to some of Australia's leading `entrepreneurs' call into question the effectiveness of the Reserve Bank's prudential supervision of the banking system. It does seem that the Reserve Bank has been concerned about this for some time. On 29 January this year the Reserve Bank issued a Press release-Prudential Statement No. 15-which concerned the prudential supervision of Australian banks' large exposures. The Press release states:

The Reserve Bank has now asked each bank to give it prior notification of the bank's intention to enter into an exceptionally large exposure to an individual client or group of related clients. It has indicated that in such cases a bank should be able to show that the proposed exposure would not result in it undertaking an excessive risk.

What has been going on? Clearly, before the stock market collapse, some entrepreneurial companies had large amounts outstanding, essentially to finance the purchase of shares. Not only the trading banks, but also a number of State banks-the people's banks-now face the risk of default on interest and principal payments. I ask: Why are State banks, the so-called people's banks, lending large amounts of money on an unsecured basis to entrepreneurial companies for the purchase of shares? No one criticises the purchase of shares. We encourage it. But we do ask the question: Why have the people's banks been lending significant amounts of money on an unsecured basis for the purchase of such shares? If there is money to be made in our community equally there is money to be lost.

I think there are two issues here. One is the prudential supervision of the banking system itself. Serious questions have to be asked about the effectiveness of the Reserve Bank in ensuring that the risk exposure of banks is not unduly high. The second issue concerns the role of State banks and State government insurance companies. A very notable element and player in this has been a group under the Labor flag in Western Australia. This group has been financing some of these entrepreneurs. More important is the role of these State government organisations in the event that these entrepreneurs, and I will use the rather colourful term of Dr Morgan, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, `hit the fence . . . and if they do so, whether they exit in an orderly-for example, via mergers-or disorderly fashion'. This whole question has been touched on by officers in the Treasury and there are other colourful expressions for `hitting the fence'.

As I said, in Western Australia we have already seen the State Government Insurance Corporation purchase substantial assets. How was this financed? Was it a consortium of State banks or other government organisations? The public has to be made aware that there is effectively-despite what the Treasurer says here-an implicit government guarantee applying to the loans of these enterprises. I have asked questions in the House of the Treasurer before today concerning the extent of the implicit guarantee provided to State government financial authorities. I have had no satisfactory answers. And I did not get any today. Australian taxpayers have a right to know the extent to which Labor governments are supporting, with either explicit or implicit guarantees, these rescue packages.

The question can be put in this way: is the Treasurer more willing for the Government to support imprudential lending than he is to bite the bullet on government expenditure and wages policy? Reductions in the size of government would release resources from the non-tradable public sector to the tradable goods sector, helping to improve the current account deficit. The position is not as the Government would say. Far from driving the economy through the floor, cuts in government expenditure would pave the way for a reduction in taxes and in government borrowing. Incentive would be improved and, of course, investment would be stimulated.

If the adverse effects of the stock market collapse are to be minimised, we have reiterated, the Government has to act and act quickly. The main reasons why the Government refuses to take early action are not economic, as some outside may suspect. The reasons, as is known by all in this Parliament and not just by honourable members on this side of the House, are bluntly political: the pending New South Wales election and the Government's attempt to prop up its mate, Unsworth. As a secondary factor, if it can slip into 1988 it can make cuts off the Forward Estimates, the wish list, rather than what it should have done-had the mini-Budget now and cut into actual programs. Seeking a cosy relationship with the trade union leadership is an additional element.

The Government's lack of political courage is further evidenced by its inability to push through on notions such as privatisation. The Hawke Government's third term was to be the term that was marked by the foray on microeconomic policy. The first one adduced was privatisation, and it hit the wall. Already the confusion on either ideological or economic grounds is pronounced. The key should be deregulating the commercial environment and then privatising government enterprises to ensure that resources are used most efficiently. This is not even being addressed by the Government. There is the real danger that the Government, in an effort to maximise revenue rather than efficiency, will sell off part or all of some enterprises without deregulating the industry. Of course, that merely transforms a government monopoly into a private monopoly. In terms of improving the infrastructure of the Australian economy-transport and communications-under this great aegis of microeconomic reform, hardly anything is achieved. The Government's apparent failure to recognise this and to act on it makes one wonder about the strength of its commitment to microeconomic reform.

Indeed, I was not intending to raise the question of the labour market but, just in passing, what does the Government do? It bows to pressure from trade union leaders to support a flat $6.50 per week wage increase in the current national wage case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus the 4 per cent training allowance.

—Indeed. What an incentive that is for employers to take on apprentices and younger workers. The trade union leadership appears to be more interested in keeping those already in work happy rather than in freeing up the labour market so that more jobs are available. The reality is that, under the corporatism of this Government, it is too petrified to take on the trade union movement which is an essential part of its government edifice. On top of this, the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions apparently are in cahoots to bring about an amalgamation of the trade unions to further the corporatism which is pervading the Australian economy. On that topic, we need to deregulate industrial relations, to expose both product and labour markets to competition and to force the pace of adjustment on our external debt so that we can better weather the storm.

SPEECH.PARA: But we raise this matter of public importance in the dying stages of this session to remind the Government of what happens every month when the figures come out and its response is, `They are not too bad, you know'. It defies logic that each month the Government adds nearly $1 billion to this nation's debt and so ratchets up the problems of the Australian economy, turning a blind eye to the essential solutions which ought to have been faced and which have been proffered by the Opposition throughout this session.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with the first point. First, the pre-crash condition of the international economy was stronger than had been anticipated. The United States had a growth rate of one per cent in real terms in the September quarter, and the Japanese industrial production to September had increased by 5 per cent. It is important to note, in relation to the point of view of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that inventories are at a very low ebb around the world and, in respect of raw materials especially, that will maintain major commodity prices. Furthermore, before the crash there was an easing of monetary policy in the nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and, while the West Germans especially have printed money, which presents a major problem in terms of inflation, that is not a new phenomenon. Therefore, the Australian policy response is quite appropriate-to wait and see. All of this is reflected in the OECD forecast of a reduction in the world growth rate from 2.75 per cent to 2.25 per cent-in other words, not depression, not the recession that honourable members opposite keep talking about with the world as we know it ending, but rather presenting no substantial reason for a major policy U-turn as honourable members opposite have implied.

It is complemented by the positive signs on commodity prices of the State Bank of Victoria. The declining American dollar, it is important to note, will boost producer returns together with the underlying buoyant world economy. The Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in today's Australian Financial Review, also gives merit to this. All these factors are in addition to an underlying optimism that we can quite rightly feel about the shape of the Australian economy. Indeed, the pre-crash condition of the Australian economy was much better than we had previously thought. That can be measured in terms of the current account deficit for year on year, the increase in exports by 12 per cent as opposed to only a 0.1 per cent increase in imports and, of course, a number of other major indices prior to the crash painted a much brighter picture for the Australian economy, and I refer to retail sales, private dwelling approvals and the average weekly earnings pattern that has evolved under this Government, giving confidence to the Australian business sector.

It must be said that the aim of this Government's policies has been to pursue the direction of resources away from private consumption to the export sector and import replacement. We as a Government are seeking to reduce Australia's dependence on commodity exports and, of course, we are pursuing structural change over time. Those honourable members opposite, by contrast, seem to imply that policy by cliche can produce results overnight; yet they come into this House without one substantial proposal to alter Australia's current position.

It is important to note that the international situation in terms of commodity prices and world economic health, with sober but realistic assessments for world growth in the ensuing year, are all set against the background of substantial policy results by this Government. Those substantial policy results have reduced the Budget deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product from 3.1 per cent under the now Leader of the Opposition to zero in the last Budget, reducing the Government's call on funds by reducing the public sector borrowing requirement from 3.4 per cent of gross domestic product to 1.8 per cent, increasing the share of national income going to profits and reducing the share to the wage and salary sector.

Of course, the restructuring of the tax regime and, in particular, full dividend imputation are the kinds of policies that the business community has to look forward to in the year ahead. The accord continues to maintain a wage and salary equilibrium in the economy. Real labour costs have been reduced and the lowest level of disputation is being maintained at a sustained level that the Australian economy has not seen since World War II.

While there is no reason for anyone in this House to be an unbridled optimist about the Australian economy in the year ahead in an uncertain world economy, there is, nevertheless, substantial reason for those opposite not to continue to deliberately talk down the economy and not to continue to deliberately berate the Australian Government's policies at home and abroad. It seems that those opposite have spent much of today saying nothing in the time allotted to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and have been more intent on pursuing disruption in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indicative of the contempt in which this Government is to be held at present that, in this matter of considerable public importance in the current economic circumstances in Australia, it puts in not a second stringer but a third stringer to answer the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). We are dealing today with a fundamentally important economic problem, the magnitude of our economic debt and the constraint that that debt places on our economic performance. I am fascinated, and indeed appalled, at the way the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers in this Government go around the country trying to make things look much better than they are, trying to paint the picture that things are going to be fine; in simple terms, trying to hold the situation together until we can get through to the New South Wales election which the Government hopes the Australian Labor Party will win in the early part of next year. In these terms, the key economic question, in the way this Government poses it, is whether the Treasurer will be able to hold things together until that time.

SPEECH.PARA: How can the Government be complacent about our debt levels in the current economic circumstances? I am absolutely staggered that people on the other side of the House can look at a debt level of $100 billion and accept it so complacently. We have a debt problem of a very significant order of magnitude and one that has quadrupled since the early 1980s. From 1983 to 1987 the level of our international debt has quadrupled. We now pay $1 in $4 of our exports just to service the interest payments on those debts; and $1 in every $3 to meet the contractual principal repayments and interest on that debt. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, we are borrowing additional money day by day, month by month, simply to meet the interest payments on those debts. It is something of the order of $1,000m per month. How is it that this Government is so complacent? How is it that the Government can be so irresponsible and so negligent in its attitude to what is a very serious and difficult set of economic circumstances?

In the few minutes I have available I will emphasise the magnitude of the task that is before us as far as our international debts are concerned. Whatever these people say, whatever time they try to buy, the seriousness of our debt problem will ultimately come home to roost in a very significant way for this Government and this Treasurer in the next few years.

I refer honourable members to a study that was done by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) in October 1986. It looked at the circumstances under which our debt might stabilise. The Treasurer refers quite often with fondness to this study as being indicative of the fact that our debt problem is coming to an end. That study suggests that to stabilise our external debt, relative to our gross domestic product (GDP), there must be a sufficient surplus in our trade balance to offset any positive contribution to foreign debt accumulation from the servicing cost of the current debt. That study estimated, for example, that it would take a trade surplus, as distinct from a trade deficit, which we presently have, of about 0.7 per cent of GDP in order to stabilise our debt at about 400 per cent by the early 1990s.

To give some perspective, if we look back to the 1960s and 1970s it is interesting to see that our balance of trade averaged a deficit of about 0.3 per cent of GDP and it is currently about 0.7 per cent relative to GDP. Those orders of magnitude suggest that we have a very long way to go in order to create the circumstances that EPAC would have us believe would be necessary to stabilise our international debts. But, in fact, it is worse than that. If we look at the EPAC study and the assumptions under which it was done, we see that it made three key assumptions. It firstly assumed that our growth rate would have to be about 3 per cent per annum in real terms; secondly, we would have to maintain the real interest rates-then about 4 1/2 per cent; and, thirdly, we would have to maintain a constant real exchange rate. None of those three conditions is likely to apply to any significant extent in the years to come. They were not applying at the time of the last Budget and they certainly are not applying now in circumstances after the stock market crash.

If we look at that EPAC study we can also get some measure of the sensitivity of our economic predicament, in particular its estimates of what trade surplus will be required to stabilise our debts if we change some of those parameters. For example, if our growth rate falls from 3 per cent to one per cent, which cannot be ruled out as the prospective growth rate for the next couple of years, the required balance of trade surplus jumps from about 0.7 per cent of GDP to about 1 1/2 per cent of GDP-we are, as I have said before, a long way from even beginning that process under the favourable assumptions of EPAC-and the magnitude of our adjustment task will be about twice as great. We are going to need a trade surplus of about 1 1/2 per cent of GDP in each of the next few years to stabilise our debt.

That study also offers one additional interesting dimension which has a direct bearing on what the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) said, which is of concern to us on this side of the House, namely, that we continue to emphasise the need for quicker policy adjustment. The EPAC study quite interestingly has some data that is helpful in that respect. The figures I quoted were of the trade surplus required to stabilise our debt at about 40 per cent of GDP, which is about the current level of our debt to GDP ratio. If we continue to let the situation slide, if we do not act and the proportion of our debt to GDP continues to grow, as it does every day and every hour that we continue to go on without doing something about that problem, the magnitude of the adjustment task becomes significantly greater. For example, if we let that ratio slip as far as EPAC suggests by way of example, to around 60 per cent of GDP, we would have to have a trade surplus of about one per cent, or a little more relative to GDP on a sustained basis. So we are in a very unreal world when the Treasurer and other Ministers in this Government can simply wander around the country trying to create the appearance that there is nothing significantly wrong with our current circumstances when those sorts of fundamental trends are there and growing day by day. The bottom line for the Government is that our international debts are a significant problem and they will get worse every day that we have to wait for the Treasurer to respond.

In much of what I have said I put weight on the outlook for our economic growth. I am surprised that the Treasurer can suggest that the stock market crash will not have a significant effect on our growth. As a defence, he runs around the place saying that things are a lot better than the Government thought at the time of the Budget and so, even if our growth falls off a bit, it will not fall off very much, from his Budget estimates, and so on. If we think back to 1984 and 1985 and some of the things he said then, we will realise that he has learnt very little from any of his past mistakes. He always tends to paint a better picture than is in fact the case. So on a couple of occasions he has ultimately had to come out with pretty inflationary rhetoric, such as the `banana republic' statement, in order to attempt to change the nature of the unreal impression he has created. And that will happen again as we go into the early part of next year. We can be sure this Treasurer will be faced with the reality of our debt problem, the reality of our debt service burden, and will again have to try to shift the nature of the debate from the impression he has been so carefully building up prior to the New South Wales election. As our growth will probably fall off quite significantly in the course of the next 12 or 18 months, it is hard to see how there is not a clear recognition on the part of the Treasurer of that fact. He forecast in the last Budget that our GDP would grow by about 2 3/4 per cent. Since then, as I have said, we have had a major stock market crash. We also have in prospect very difficult international trading circumstances and our commodity prices, which have encouragingly shown some recovery lately, are most likely, as today's Australian Financial Review, for example, suggests, to flatten out around the middle of next year. How on earth will he be able to sustain our growth rate, which has been so importantly dependent on our external performance, in what will be very difficult international circumstances? Most international commentators are now reassessing the outlook for the United States of America and are now significantly reducing their earlier forecasts for growth in that country. Earlier growth figures of about 2 3/4 per cent have now been reduced quite significantly to about one per cent and, in some cases, some private sector forecasters in the United States are suggesting that growth could be as low as 0.1 per cent in 1988.

Let me conclude with a simple plea to the Treasurer. Our debt levels are a serious economic problem. We are in the most difficult set of economic circumstances in the post-war period. I do not know how we can genuinely wander around the country complacently trying to create the impression that things are on the mend, when the magnitude of our debt is what it is, and when our debt service burden is growing month by month and is crippling this nation and its capacity to continue to grow and develop. I think he owes the people of Australia a significant explanation for that irresponsible behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members to look at the terms of the Opposition's matter of public importance. It refers to the need for the Government to take immediate-I emphasise the word `immediate'-policy action to reduce the vulnerability of Australia in light of our huge foreign debt. A number of aspects of this proposal warrant consideration. The Opposition talks about the need for immediate action to reduce our vulnerability which has resulted from the magnitude of our foreign debt. What does it have in mind in that regard? Presumably, it has in mind some fiscal policy, wages policy or perhaps even monetary policy-in other words, short term measures relating to the macroeconomic environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not dispute for a moment that the macroeconomic environment is relevant to these issues; in fact, it obviously is. However, if the foreign debt problem and our balance of payments problem is to be corrected in the longterm, nobody seriously disputes that what is required is major structural change to our economy. We need to reduce our dependence on commodity exports-agricultural and mineral commodities-and increase the value added component in our exports, by moving into the area of highly processed manufactured goods and sophisticated services. Everybody agrees that is the essence of the real solution to the problem. That is what is required in order to correct the difficulty in the long term.

The problem with the proposal that the Opposition has put forward is the notion that somehow there is a set of immediate policy measures that can be taken that will significantly address the problem. On the contrary, I argue that to place reliance on immediate policy measures as distinct from policies oriented to the medium to long term is fundamentally wrong. If one pursues a fiscal policy which is so tight and so restrictive that one must cut back and put the squeeze on necessary areas of government spending-on, say, education, infrastructure and structural adjustment for industry-one is eliminating the preconditions of major structural change in the economy and, in that sense, being thoroughly counterproductive. I think that the basic perspective embodied in this matter of public importance is fundamentally flawed.

It is interesting also, given the Opposition's emphasis on fiscal policy, that no doubt it would tell us that what the Government should have done, in light of the stock market crash, was immediately to bring down an economic statement and to tighten the fiscal screws significantly. That is what it would say ought to be done. Of course, if one looks at the Opposition's record with regard to fiscal policy, one has no reason to suppose that it would do at all well in that area. When this Government came to power there was a $10 billion Budget deficit in prospect. I hesitate to mention that, because if I hear it referred to once more in a parliamentary debate, I think I will throw up. I am sick to death of hearing about it, but it happens to be true.

Of course, the Government has addressed a major fiscal problem very effectively and in a way in which no other government in the post-war period in this country has managed to do. There are very few precedents, even internationally, for the way in which fiscal policy has been tightened up by this Government over the last few years. The winding back of the Budget deficit to zero per cent of gross domestic product is rather unusual, to say the least. We must ask ourselves what the Opposition would do. Is there anything in its policies or proposals to suggest that it would do better than that in the fiscal policy area? Of course, the only thing we have to go on is its stated policies. Its pre-election policies were shown conclusively to be an arithmetical absurdity; there is no argument about that. They were an absolute joke that would have blown out the Budget deficit enormously. Yet the Opposition expects to have its views taken seriously on the fiscal policy front. It is an absolute farce. To the extent that it is saying to the Government, `Yes, you should have been tighter on fiscal policy', what it put forward is utterly laughable and can be dismissed.

On the fiscal policy front, there is a lot of discussion in academic literature about what the relationship is between the Budget deficit on the one hand and the current account deficit on the other, what that does to the capital account and, in turn, what that does to the level of our foreign debt. There is a presumption on the part of those who say that the key to getting the current account deficit down is to squeeze the Budget deficit. There is the so-called twin deficit hypothesis which supposes a fairly close linkage between the Budget deficit and the current account deficit. I think that that close linkage is frequently exaggerated.

I do not dispute that there is a connection between the Budget deficit and the current account deficit, but I do not think it is as strong as many people argue. In fact, I have seen some literature regarding the theoretical and empirical evidence on that question, and it is a lot more ambiguous than many people imagine. Nonetheless, I believe that to rely on fiscal policy as the means of addressing our current account deficit is wrong. Basically, we need to have a range of both short and long term policies and, in particular, the key issue is to address the structural problem. That requires policies geared over the medium to long term. This Government has shown that it is capable of performing incomparably better, in terms of both short term policy and long term industry restructuring policy, than the Opposition.

When the Opposition carries on about the vulnerability of our economy, the question that has to be asked is this: What reason is there to suppose that our admittedly significant problem with external indebtedness would be made better by the stated policy proposals of the Opposition, its performance in government and since, in terms of what it put forward by way of pre-election policies? There is no reason to think that it would do better and every reason to think that it would do vastly worse. It would destroy an existing framework of incomes policy. If its statements are to be taken seriously, it would utterly destroy any coherent fiscal policy. It has no coherent approach to industry restructure and, if anything, its proposals would make our existing difficulties far worse.

There are some legitimate issues relating to the factors that have led to external indebtedness blowing out over the last few years. Some relate to the currency depreciation which has increased the Australian dollar valuation of our external indebtedness. Also, on the capital accounts side, the stock market boom, for example, has led to a larger magnitude of capital inflow than might have otherwise been the case. To that extent, that may well be driving the current account deficit, rather than the conventional wisdom of the current account deficit determining the capital account deficit. An Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development publication entitled Financial Market Trends dated November 1987 reported that in Australia prior to the collapse surging equity markets continued to attract large capital inflows. One suspects that that and the associated spate of takeover activity may have been a contributing factor to the build-up of the private sector component of our external indebtedness. I do not think that that can be neglected.

It is perhaps worth noting that the bulk of our external indebtedness is incurred by the private sector. We see a lot of nonsense in speeches by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) about the $110 billion of gross external indebtedness. That works out at $7,000 per head of population. We are told that every man, woman and child in Australia is in hock to the tune of $7,000. Of course there is a lot of nonsense involved in that suggestion. I would have thought that, if we are looking at the debt incurred by private companies, the people who are in hock if anybody is, or who are liable for that indebtedness, are the companies' shareholders, not the general population. The taxpayers are responsible for the Government component of our external indebtedness, both the Commonwealth's official borrowing and also borrowings by government owned enterprises. But certainly the suggestion that every Australian is in some sense liable for borrowings by Bond or Holmes a Court to finance their takeover activities is a preposterous proposition and it shows an absurd approach to this issue.

I think it is better to have all matters dealt with through the review processes as they are on the appeals. That is the basis of the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept the reasoning of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I can understand his concern about flexibility. However, clause 19, to which he wants to add this addition, deals with an appeal, which is actually in the province of the High Court of Australia. The provision is of a similar nature to that which already applies under the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966. There, in an appeal to the Full Court, the Court shall have regard only to the evidence given in proceedings out of which the appeal arose. That is section 17a (10), and, in the same Act, section 18 (5) says the same thing. That is based on the principle that, on appeal, one is dealing with the matters that were raised at the original hearing. I am reminded of the fact that that is consistent with rules governing appeals in criminal matters before the courts. Under those rules, no new evidence is permitted because one must deal with the issue that was before the court at the original hearing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear to the honourable gentleman. The matters in extradition are rather limited, as he knows, and he has been arguing about the prima facie case. The matters that can be raised before the magistrate are specific matters. They include dual criminality, identity, a sufficiency of documents, compliance with treaty requirements and matters that go to proving extradition objections. All of these things are known to the person sought at the time, so to depart from the practice and say that something else will now happen opens the issue and results in a trial de novo. For that reason, particularly because it is extradition that we are talking about, it is consistent to say, `These are the only matters that can be argued on appeal. They must be the same matters as were dealt with by the magistrate'. Otherwise there is a brand new proposition, with attempts to put something additional before the court of appeal to that which was put before the magistrate. The issue must be looked at. It is acknowledged that if other matters were to arise-of a humanitarian nature or something of that sort-one would come into the discretion area, but not in this formality of appeal.

I want to make a point that might be helpful in terms of the prima facie case. If the honourable gentleman gives me this licence, he will be pleased to know that on 17 November in the House of Lords, the House rejected an amendment from the Opposition that there should be brought into the legislation concerned a provision relating to evidence of a prima facie case. It was being done away with. I had not read this before I spoke earlier today. The Lord Chancellor says about that matter:

In my submission to your Lordships, the principle that we are seeking to establish here is important in giving proper effect to the development of international co-operation in connection with the suppression of crime. It is a logical step when one recognises the strengths of the legal system of others as well as our own. I believe that in order to accede to the convention it will not be necessary for us to accede to it fully. Of course, we could have a reservation but the real justification for this advance in our legislation is that the result will be effective. We want effective co-operation in relation to this matter across purely national boundaries, between legal systems with mutual respect for one another. For that reason I submit to your Lordships that the amendments in principle should be approved.
That concerned the prima facie case. The Lord Chancellor made another helpful remark. He said:
In case it is thought that the matter of prima facie evidence is fundamental to our system-
bear in mind that the proposals that he was talking about were being removed-

it is worth pointing out, first, that in cases of extradition requested by the Republic of Ireland the prima facie rule does not apply. It is entitled to extradition because of the history of our connection. The authorities in the Republic of Ireland will proceed on a proper judicial determination in this country. Therefore, it is not correct to say that this requirement-
that is, the requirement of prima facie evidence-
has been fundamental to all extraditions.
I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General goes back to the previous legislation to rebut the point that we would make in regard to this amendment. I refer him to his second reading speech in which he said that this legislation is an attempt to modernise the law and to bring about improvements. That is all that we are attempting to do with this amendment. It does not open up a Pandora's box. It is in the discretion of the courts. I stick by the amendment, which I think is reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the House of Lords, I am entertained that the Attorney-General, who I think has a secret agenda to knock down the powers of the Senate, the House of review, is here relying on the wisdom of the House of review at Westminster. As to the Irish arrangements, I make no comment. I have no knowledge of them and the Attorney-General obviously did not know about them before today either. I am not sure that he does now.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the remaining clauses, and in particular clause 22. I want to provide the Attorney- General with an opportunity to respond to the issues that we have raised in respect of the implications of this death penalty prohibition on extradition unless one has an undertaking. I would be prepared to give the Attorney-General an extension of time. We usually do on debates on his portfolio. I was thinking that if 10 minutes was not enough, we would be prepared to hang around until later in the afternoon until we could finally come up with a response to this one. The response that has been elicited so far has not been satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, the Attorney-General has got himself all tied up in red tape, then he has gone off to immigration law and the hijacking of aircraft legislation to try to get himself out of the difficult situation into which he put himself in the first place. To claim that it is a satisfactory answer to say that the immigration laws will deal with these fugitives is inadequate and inappropriate. Immigration laws are about immigration, not about dealing with major criminals. In respect of the hijacking of aircraft legislation, that might provide part of the answer, but it is limited to offences in relation to aircraft hijacking, or whatever it might be. That answer is not up to scratch.

There are scenarios under this proposal, to which the Attorney-General is apparently sticking, where his answer is totally inadequate. The implications are very considerable. The Gold Coast tourist resorts in Australia are fairly free of this sort of thing. If this proposal goes through, we shall not have the Gold Coast and we shall not have to worry about the Costa del Sol-it will be the Costa del Bowen. The Bill contains a wide invitation. We have had a lot of debate recently about war criminals. Let me set out a scenario. The Attorney-General seemed to think that this is all pie in the sky stuff, but what if there were here a serious war criminal, and a request came from a requesting country that had the death penalty for those offences, and that person was neither an Australian citizen nor a permanent resident? Given those circumstances, what would the Attorney-General do? Would he ignore that person or give him a slap over the wrist under the immigration laws?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about Australian citizens?
—No, I am talking about the implications of this legislation and the possible consequences of it.
—What about citizenship?

—I am talking about a person who is neither an Australian citizen nor a resident. What would the Attorney-General do about such a person? The answer is that there is nothing that he can do. The Attorney-General is talking himself into this situation when he does not need to do so at all. The reality is that he has very wide discretions, as he has acknowledged and as everybody knows. He is tying himself up in this situation. Basically the response that I got from the Attorney's office last Friday when I raised this matter publicly is the same response that we have got today. The response was inadequate on Friday, and it is still inadequate today. The problem will not go away. In America 37 of the 50 states still retain the death penalty.
—You are saying that I would need to alter the law to allow them to go back to be executed.

—No, it is not a question of whether they go back, because the Attorney still has a discretion. If the Attorney does not want a person to go back, that is fine. However, my point is: Why does the Attorney tie his hands? As soon as he does so there may be people who, in fact, take advantage of the situation. I have a copy of a letter addressed to the Attorney- General from the Queensland Minister for Justice and Attorney-General, Mr Clauson. He makes a very good point when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Canada, Eire, New Zealand and the United Kingdom retain capital punishment for treason as well as certain military offences. A number of European countries also retain the death penalty for certain offences, including Belgium, Spain and Greece.
We like to draw authority from the House of Lords. I have used Canada as an authority. He says:

. . . there is presently a debate in the Canadian House of Commons sponsored by the Government, on the possible re-introduction of capital punishment for murder. From information supplied to me, it appears that there is a strong likelihood that if a vote is taken Canada will restore the death penalty.

As I say, this is a trend that we have seen in recent years. I do not know how that trend will continue in the future. However, it is a reality that many of these countries will either retain the death penalty or, in the case of Canada as we understand it, may reintroduce it. I think Mr Clauson put it very well when he said:
The point of this is that it is dangerous and counter-productive for the Commonwealth to seek to refuse extradition simply because the alleged criminal may face a death sentence.

That is the point he raises. He says that he understands the humanitarian aspects of this matter-as does the Federal Opposition. In the end, the Government is picking up on a fine- sounding principle and one we can understand. However, it has implications which, quite frankly, I did not think last Friday either the Attorney-General or his Department seemed to have fully comprehended. I am disappointed that the Attorney still does not seem to comprehend them. Furthermore, he does not seem prepared to accede to the point we are putting. On page 2 of Mr Clauson's letter he says:

Taking another example, in 1985 an Australian citizen murdered over 10 women in a number of American States. In almost every State the penalty for such murders was death. As it happened that Australian citizen was killed in a shoot-out, but if he had managed to return to Australia, the Australian Government would have had to refuse extradition requests from American authorities.
There is a complication there because he was an Australian citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an Australian citizen.
—Yes, I realise that. However, the point I have made is still valid. As an example, it is still a useful contribution to the debate. Mr Clauson continued:

SPEECH.PARA: I am deeply concerned that out of some misguided `humanitarian' objectives this Bill may in fact prove to be a major impediment to effective law enforcement and the administration of justice.

Our primary aim, as I am sure is the primary aim of the Attorney-General, is the effective law enforcement and administration of justice. The provision is not needed because the Attorney-General already has the discretion. He is quite free to exercise his discretion. It is a wide and unfettered discretion. Quite frankly, it would have been much better to leave the situation as it was rather than opening up a potential situation in which Australia was regarded as a safe haven. That is not something that anybody would want. I am sure that it is not something that the Attorney-General would want. Therefore, I think that the Government ought to reconsider its position. This is a serious matter. I look forward to what the Attorney-General might say further on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), I accept the view that he feels he understands the problem completely, as does the Minister for Justice and Attorney-General in Queensland. However, neither has negotiated extradition treaties. Why? They have never had the opportunity. The fundamental flaw in the honourable member's argument is that all the countries with which we negotiate treaties accept our death penalty proviso. It is not a shock to them, as the honourable member would like to make out.
—Why put it in?

—For the very simple reason that our own law does not provide for the death penalty. In negotiating treaties we make the point that we expect the same situation to apply in regard to a particular person that a country might want to extradite.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member has created the impression that such countries do not ask for extradition. They do. In fact, people are sent back to those countries. All that has happened, apparently to the honourable member's dissatisfaction, is that such people are not executed. Such an arrangement will not create a haven. Under the terms of the treaty everybody would go back. Someone who committed a crime in California, for instance, could well be executed. If that person escaped here and his extradition were asked for that person would be sent back to California, probably to serve a life sentence. But that person would not be executed. That is the only difference. The treaty would not be a haven for such people. That happens to be the treaty that we have already negotiated.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is already covered in the treaty as you have told me, why are you going ahead with this?

—Does the honourable member not want to know that there is a statutory requirement on me to do that? Would not other countries want to know, in regard to the treaties that we negotiate with them, that that is the law of this country and that it is not something that is left to the discretion of Attorneys-General? Let me make it clear that extradition treaties relate to the laws of our country. We say to other countries `Our law is this'.
—But it is their law, not ours.
-Order!

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Chairman. The honourable member has had more than sufficient time to argue his case. The honourable member has never had the benefit of negotiating treaty arrangements. In his earlier submission he was very worried about the problems of hijacking and matters of that nature. When I told him that they could be dealt with in Australia he got straight off that subject. He is not looking at the issues. I can understand that because he has not had the benefit of being in government. That seems to be the problem. Worse still, he has never had the benefit of organising extradition treaties. Such treaties were pretty light on when I came to office. We are up to about 20 extradition negotiations now.

SPEECH.PARA: I negate completely the suggestion that people will come here and be able to remain here. They will not; they will be dealt with in accordance with the extradition treaties. It will be a different matter if they are Australian citizens. Of course, it is different if people come here who are not the subject of extradition proceedings but my ministerial colleague deports them because they are not here legally. That deportation has nothing to do with crime. The honourable gentleman is trying to say that there is a misunderstanding. There is no misunderstanding. Many people are deported. In many cases when such people are sent back they may be charged with a crime. They are not exempt from such charges.

We are clearly stating the law, as we do in the treaties themselves. When we negotiate such treaties the death penalty is clearly made an exception. All the countries with which we have negotiated extradition treaties have accepted that position. We are in line with every other country in the world. It gets back to what the Lord Chancellor in the United Kingdom has said. Even the British, after all these centuries, suddenly realise that they had better get up to date. They have agreed on this principle. The Opposition does not want to get up to date. The rules of evidence we apply in this regard have to have an international basis. Treaties are made on that basis.

The Opposition must accept that when we talk about international comity in these matters we do it by treaty. The treaty sets out the situation applying in respect of each country. In extradition cases it is made very clear that the death penalty is one of the exceptions. It is put in our law to guarantee that there is some validity and support for that exception.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF NEW UTILITY HELICOPTER FACILITIES AT RAAF BASE, TOWNSVILLE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of new utility helicopter facilities at RAAF Base, Townsville-Provision of 15 new married quarters.

The proposed work is for the construction of some 15 married quarters associated with the development of new operational and support facilities at the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Townsville. The new facilities are required to enable No. 9 Squadron, which is to be shortly re-equipped with Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters, to be relocated from the base at Amberley to Townsville. The development of the new facilities was referred to the Public Works Committee (PWC) on 23 October last year. Following the tabling of the favourable report in this House on 2 April this year the Government considered it was expedient for the works to proceed. Construction has since commenced. When tabling the report, the Public Works Committee expressed concern at the apparent high cost of construction of the 15 houses and called for supplementary submissions addressing issues relating to the delivery and cost of the houses.

The Committee tabled its supplementary report on 4 June this year. This report recommended that there was a need to construct the 15 houses and that they be constructed on existing defence owned land using the most economical method of delivery. Detailed investigations by my officers and those of the Department of Defence have indicated that the blocks already owned by Defence are not suitable for the dwellings to be constructed. The existing blocks are deficient in size, orientation and location for the standard of housing proposed. These blocks were originally purchased in 1982-83 for group one; that is, other ranks accommodation. To now construct the proposed houses on the existing blocks would result in over capitalisation and it would be a poor investment decision. Earlier this year more suitable blocks were identified and were estimated to cost up to $25,000 each. It is now intended to acquire 15 suitable blocks this financial year at a cost of $375,000. It is also intended to construct defence houses on the existing blocks at a later date as part of the ongoing housing program.

Normally the replacement of houses for other rank personnel would require acquisition of blocks at a cost of $20,000 each. By using the existing 15 blocks, some $300,000 will be saved in later years, albeit at an additional cost now of $375,000 that I identified earlier. The cost of the houses when initially referred was $1.4m at October 1986 prices and to this is added the land acquisition cost to give a revised total project cost of $1.775m.

My officers have undertaken a detailed study of the most economical method of delivery. There are no suitable dwellings that could be purchased that would meet the requirements for housing personnel of the defence forces, nor are there project houses constructed in Townsville that would satisfy the requirements. Two other methods of delivery are available: one is acquisitions of land house packages where builders construct houses on their land. The other is design and documentation by my Department with construction by contractors. The costs of both methods are similar. The quality control of the option of my Department supervising construction of its designed houses is considered to be superior. Land house package acquisition relies on intermittent local authority and departmental site inspections. It is intended to provide the houses based on my Department's design, but contracted out to private enterprise. The cost of these houses is not high, given the sizes involved, and the blocks will need to be developed and the houses completed to a stage where they are immediately habitable by service personnel and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wouldn't they be?
—What sort of a comment is that? We are doing the right thing, are we not? We are building the houses. The honourable member sits there and makes snide comments.
—Order! The Minister should address the chair.
—It sounds as though it is something unusual.
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson will restrain himself.

—The blocks will need to be developed and the houses completed to a stage where they are immediately habitable by service personnel and their families. The cost of the houses includes a number of additional features, such as landscaping and internal fittings and finishes to meet the defence scales and standards of accommodation. Contracts will be awarded as soon as suitable buildings sites have been obtained and they should be purchased later this financial year. The houses are to be completed by late next year or early 1989 to enable the relocation of No. 9 Squadron to Townsville early in 1989. I thank the Committee for the support it has given to this proposal. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that at least this defence facility has gone to the Joint Committee on Public Works (PWC). We are not trying to sidestep that Committee, as has happened too often in the past. I think everyone is very pleased to see these new houses being constructed in Townsville, an area that I know well. I question the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) on why there are only 15 houses when he is talking about a Black Hawk squadron. We are talking about a lot of people, although I am just not sure how many. We probably need 100 houses, if not more. Is there any plan to house the rest of the squadron? I hope the Minister will take this matter on board and give us an answer. Fifteen houses will not go very far.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said in his speech a moment ago that the houses would be immediately habitable. Why would they not be habitable? Is the Minister saying that we are just going to build a box and the poor old inhabitants come along and because they are only Defence Force personnel they have to do the landscaping and gardening and make the houses habitable. Why would they not be habitable for Defence Force personnel to move in? I think that is one of the most extraordinary statements I have ever heard. I note with some concern that the PWC thought that the houses were too expensive. I am not quite sure why it thought they were too expensive, but I am suspicious enough to believe that this Government, given its record in looking after its Defence Force personnel, thought that these houses were too expensive for Defence Force personnel. If that is not true obviously I will apologise. But I am sick and tired, as are a lot of people in the community, particularly Defence Force personnel, of the Government saying, `That will be good enough for them'. When we look at some of the dog boxes that have been built in Townsville and at other places over the years, in which Defence Force personnel are still living, it is no wonder that they are fed up with the conditions that are being fed to them. When the PWC says that these houses are too expensive I ask: Too expensive for what and for whom? I would be grateful for an answer from the Government.

I noted with some satisfaction that the Minister said that the Defence Force land that had been put aside for these houses was rejected as unsuitable. That is a step in the right direction. I hope that people are now starting to consider that service men and women and their families are ordinary people like everyone else and deserve the same sort of consideration, or better consideration, than other people.

Let me come back to some of the houses that have been provided over the years-I do not attribute all the blame for this to the present Government because it has been a long process-and I wish to deal particularly with houses in Townsville. Many honourable members in the House, including the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), have seen that these are little more than dog boxes. When people moved into those houses there was no concrete underneath and no verandahs around them. How anyone can build a house in Townsville with any satisfaction and hand it over to Defence Force personnel and not put a verandah on it is completely beyond me. I have not seen the plan for these houses that we are discussing. I very much hope that we will get a decent design-apparently the Minister's Department has undertaken a design-for the tropical area into which these Defence Force personnel are going. I was also alarmed at some of the Minister's other remarks. He said that the land was not rejected for these houses because it was in a bad position or not good enough or not suitable for Defence Force personnel; he said that it was rejected because it was a poor investment decision. I think that reflects some of the Government's current attitudes when it is dealing with Defence Force personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that those blocks were not good enough for the houses.
—They would be overcapitalised. It was not because the blocks were not suitable for the people.
—For God's sake, read the speech.
—I have read it. It was not because the blocks were not suitable for the people; it was because it would have represented a poor investment decision. That is the point I am making.
—It would have been overcapitalisation to build those types of houses on those blocks.
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.

—It would have been much better if the Minister had said that the land was not suitable for the people instead of talking in commercial terms about the Defence Force personnel who might have to live in the houses. I also very much hope-I think the Minister mentioned this-that these houses will be built to Army scales and standards, but we have heard that story before. The fact is that about 12,000 out of the current 22,000 houses owned by the Department of Defence are below those scales and standards and are unsuitable.

SPEECH.PARA: I very much hope that some of the lessons of the past have been learnt. Housing is one of the biggest problems causing this enormous wastage from the Services. Everyone I have spoken to in the last year or so who has left the Services has mentioned the poor standard of housing in which they have to live. How we can expect to retain bright men and women who are highly qualified and highly skilled when their standard of housing keeps on slipping below what it now regarded as the community norm-the standard that most people live in-is utterly beyond me.

The Government has said that it will spend $75m on housing over the next 10 years. That commitment is welcome but I put it to the Government that that will not be enough. One of the reasons it will not be enough is that there is a sleight of hand trick in that $75m. This year half of that will go on new housing in brand new bases. Originally, when the Government talked about that $75m, it mentioned that it expected that that would be spent on new and renovated housing in existing bases. The fact is that half of that will go to Tindal and Rockingham, which are new bases. So only $30m-odd will be left for some of the badly needed renovations and new housing in existing areas.

In conclusion, legislation recently went through this House to set up the Defence Force Housing Authority and I think both sides of the House agreed that that will be an effective organisation. We certainly hope that it will be. We wish it the best in trying to rectify some of the horrendous problems that exist in Defence Force housing. As I have said, I hope that the 15 houses that will be built at Townsville will be built to proper scales and standards and might set a standard that will encourage people to stay in the defence forces instead of getting out in droves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and his Department on the work that they have done in ensuring that the 15 new houses to be constructed in Townsville to meet the accommodation needs of personnel to be stationed at Garbutt air base, Townsville, for the new Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopter facility will be of a standard which will be the envy of service personnel around this country. The cost of the 15 new houses is $1.77m. They will be designed to a standard which not only will take into account the tropical environment but also will meet the expectations of defence spouses who have made a number of submissions to the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses in relation to the design of service homes. I refer to such things as the provision of screening in a tropical environment to ensure that insects do not intrude into their homes; the need for concreting underneath the homes; and the need to ensure that the kitchen and bathroom facilities in the homes are also able to cope with the climatic conditions of a hot, wet environment. SPEECH.PARA: This motion by the Minister to refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Public Works for approval of the work is significant. Not only has he moved for approval of this work; he has foreshadowed also that there will be additional dwellings. SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to clear up several points which I think the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) did not understand when I spoke to my motion requesting expediency for this project. The honourable member mentioned that construction of 15 houses was perhaps not adequate to provide enough housing accommodation to cover the relocation of No. 9 Squadron from Amberley to Townsville and, of course, that is so. I never intended to imply in my speech that the 15 houses constituted the total housing program which would be required to cover this move. DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMONWEALTH OFFICES, HAYMARKET, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of new Commonwealth offices, Haymarket, New South Wales.

In accordance with our policy of increasing ownership of office accommodation requirements, and therefore reducing the overall rental outlays, I propose to construct some 50,000 square metres net of office accommodation at the Haymarket in Sydney on Commonwealth land known as the Australian Gaslight site. It may be recalled that I mentioned this matter last night when talking about our total overall rental and ownership accommodation strategy for the city of Sydney. This site is a complete city block at the southern end of the central business district bounded by Pitt, Barlow, Park and Hay Streets.

It is well positioned in relation to public transport, being only some five minutes walk from both the Central Railway Station and the bus interchange at Railway Square. The site contains a number of historic buildings, which I am advised will be classified by the Australian Heritage Commission. These include the former Australian Gaslight Showroom, Fire Engine House and the Presbyterian Manse. The proposal will provide for restoration of these buildings and their incorporation into the overall development.

The site also contains a number of retail facilities. To take advantage of the full development potential of the site, the proposal includes some 1,200 square metres of new retail commercial accommodation which will be leased on the open market. DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADE OF ARMY LIVING-IN ACCOMMODATION AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS AUSTRALIA-WIDE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

The bulk of the Army's living-in barracks accommodation for its single soldiers was built in the 1960s. Obviously it was built by a former conservative government and it was of a quite low standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair go! You can't help yourself.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF RADIO AND ORCHESTRA FACILITIES FOR THE ABC AND SBS AT ULTIMO, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the ABC and SBS at Ultimo, New South Wales.

The proposed public work is the construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and radio facilities for the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) on a site at Harris Street, Ultimo, Sydney. Currently the ABC and SBS operate those services from 16 separate locations around the central business district of Sydney. Of these, only one was purpose designed, the remainder having been adapted from commercial offices, factories and a cinema. Three properties are owned by the ABC with the remainder occupied on a leasehold basis. The ABC has costed the savings likely to be achieved by the proposed facility at approximately $10.2m per annum. This takes into account projected rent and staff savings and other operational efficiencies.

Cabinet, in May 1986, approved the purchase of the Ultimo site on the basis that the three ABC owned properties would be sold, and also agreed to the provision of $2m of Budget funds in 1986-87 to cover design consultant fees. In May this year, Cabinet further approved the project proceeding under an instalment purchase funding arrangement within a building cost limit of $95m at February 1987 prices. The bulk of repayments are to come from the identified operational savings.

The proposal provides for construction of a 39,800 square metre building over 10 levels, comprising offices, studio-production suites, a 700-seat rehearsal and recording hall, plus other public and support facilities. A feature of the building will be the central spine, designated as `studio capable' floor area, which will incorporate special provisions to ensure full acoustic isolation of studios. The `on air' studios will also have views over the city and Darling Harbour. The building includes all normal engineering services. In addition, it will incorporate comprehensive provisions to ensure an appropriate acoustic environment in all studio, production, recording and rehearsal areas and to maintain essential power supplies in the event of mains failure. Because of the importance of radio services in times of an emergency, special attention is also being paid to building security.

As a separate part of the proposal, the ABC intends to construct a 520 space car park on the balance of the site. One hundred of these spaces will be permanently required for use by the ABC and SBS. The additional car parking spaces, when not required for ABC or SBS purposes, will be available for commercial hire and are expected to produce an attractive annual revenue return of approximately $0.75m. Design is being undertaken by private sector consultants and further design documentation and construction will be undertaken on a project management basis, with construction packages to be publicly tendered for.

Subject to Public Works Committee (PWC) endorsement and government approval, it is planned that siteworks will commence in April-May 1988. The main building construction is scheduled to start in mid-July 1988, with an estimated total building construction period of 30 months. The estimated capital cost of the main building and separate carpark is $19m at February 1987 prices. This is the most significant public work to be undertaken by the ABC in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Ninety-one million dollars. The economies of operation should materially improve as a result of ABC and SBS co-location at the new Ultimo site. I table the plans of the proposed work and commend to the House the motion to refer the work for PWC consideration.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, reform of methods and deliberations in this Parliament move very slowly. It is very difficult to obtain change. TALK.START.PARA: —The five motions being considered are of course designed to amend Standing Orders to provide improved opportunities for private members to raise matters in the House.
