The report was completed in May of this year just prior to the elections.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman of the Committee of course was the former member for Bowman, Mr Len Keogh, and my colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) was Deputy Chairman. Both these gentlemen are highly regarded by honourable members on both sides of the House and both, of course, are very experienced parliamentarians. The other members of the Committee, also experienced parliamentarians, were the former member for Denison, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). The honourable member for Grayndler of course is currently Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees.

The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), another of my colleagues and a Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees, was a very active member and made a tremendous contribution to the work of the Committee. Last but certainly not least, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), who is currently the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, was a member of that Committee. I compliment all of those honourable gentlemen who served on that Committee because whilst there will be opposition expressed to some of the recommendations, and indeed the Government has not brought forward all of the recommendations with its blessing, I think the House owes those members who were responsible for this report a debt of gratitude.

It is important that the House from time to time examine and re-examine the procedures and ensure that they remain relevant and appropriate for the time. The Committee, I think, has done an excellent job albeit that we may not agree with all of the recommendations. Over recent years, unfortunately, there has been a tendency for the Executive, as far as possible, to disregard Parliament and the views of private members. The changes to our Standing Orders that are proposed, particularly in the first three motions which we are addressing at the moment, will go some way to altering this perception. The Opposition will not oppose the first three motions which deal with the routine of business on Thursday mornings; the omission of standing order 10, which stipulates that no General Business, except of a formal character, can be discussed before the Address-in-Reply has been adopted; and the change in procedure for tabling ministerial papers. We will, however, carefully monitor the operation of these new practices to ensure that there are no unintended consequences.

I think it is also important to highlight a view shared by many members that it will be necessary for us to review the whole of our procedures and practices when we move into the new Parliament House. When the Government's response was tabled, the Leader of the House made reference to that and he also referred to the fact that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) also had made that observation on a previous occasion. When we discuss the remaining two motions, dealing with the proposal to reduce the quorum of the House from a third of the members to a fifth and the reading of speeches, I will have something further to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Young). At the same time I congratulate the Leader of the House and thank him for the assistance that he has given to the Standing Committee on Procedure during its deliberations. As the current Chairman of the Committee, I know the hard work that was put in by the members of the previous Committee and the former Chairman, Mr Len Keogh. The purpose of the matters before the House at present which are the subject of this cognate debate is to give honourable members the opportunity to bring matters of concern before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: With the increase in membership and the amount of legislation there has been a gradual diminution in the time available to individual members in which they can bring private or electoral business before the House. This is not a criticism of the Government of the day, because the increasing pressure of legislative necessities has been of such nature to inhibit time available for private members' business. The Procedure Committee has therefore come forward with proposals which, it is considered, will go a long way to giving honourable members of the House sufficient time to bring matters of interest or private members' Bills before the House for consideration.

The proposals presently before the House provide for each Thursday morning's sitting to be set aside for private members. The routine of business proposed for each sitting Thursday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. is shown in tabular form in the report and also in the letter that I recently distributed to all honourable members. I do not propose to go through all those matters at this stage because the Opposition has indicated that it is generally in agreement with the Committee's report and certainly in agreement with the three matters presently under consideration. It will bring back to private members opportunities that they do not have at the present time. The situation in regard to the introduction of private members' Bills will be given the regard which it is due. At the present time, it is quite difficult for private members to introduce legislation. If the proposals are carried here today, I believe that they will go a long way to encouraging members to bring legislation before the House for proper discussion.

The major purpose of the Thursday morning proposals is not only to enable members to bring in private members' Bills but also to link in with the current grievance debate, which is at the moment held on only one Thursday morning each two-week sittings. Under our proposal, the grievance debate will be available for members on each Thursday morning. Although a number of expressions were made at Committee meetings that perhaps we are straying a little away from what one might call grievances during that debate-because almost anything can be debated, not only members' grievances-the Committee considered that it should remain as it is. It will be up to members to bring before the House the subjects that they wish to introduce, rather than going back to some narrowly defined lines.

The 90-second statements, which are also proposed for a quarter of an hour during that morning will, I believe, be popular with honourable members. It proved tremendously popular in the House of Commons in Canada, although honourable members might think that 90 seconds is a reasonably short period of time. The Procedure Committee recommendation to the Government was that that should be held on each day, but we bowed to the Government wish that we should have such a debate once a week rather than every day. I am of the opinion that that segment will be very popular with honourable members, and perhaps in the future we may be able to bring some pressure to bear on the Government because of that popularity.

We realise that the adjournment debate each evening will be shortened by a quarter of an hour to accommodate the matters that will be dealt with on Thursday mornings. However, the additional time allotted to members on Thursday morning is quite significant. Six hours will be allotted to private members business, compared to 2 1/2 hours at the present time. We believe that if the House adopts these procedures, not only will that be popular with members, but also, because of the new Parliament House-which will be more a people's House than this House because of the increased space that will be given to the public and because parliamentarians will be under greater scrutiny there than they are here-that will be of significance.

I take on board the suggestion made by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), the Leader of Opposition Business in the House, that we shall need to give attention to procedures in the new building. I assure the House that the Procedure Committee is also of that opinion, and any further reports or investigations that the Committee conducts will take into consideration the move into that House in August next year. We shall not be making further proposals on the conduct of business in this House. All of our future deliberations will be angled to what will be happening in that new House. I believe that there will be quite a deal of work for us in that project. I commend the motion to the House and I hope that the House adopts it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by referring to the former Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, Mr Len Keogh. Perhaps the role of a committee member looking at procedures is not that greatly appreciated, judging by the award meted out to him. I will seek to keep my comments short and to the point. I acknowledge the efforts of Mr Keogh's successor, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford) and the secretariat that served us, and I do so with considerable appreciation. As the Chairman has just said, there will be a need in the new Parliament House to re-examine all our procedures, because that place will be totally different from this. I hope that the Committee will go on to a marking time period until that happens.

SPEECH.PARA: I see no problem in the new procedures, and I noticed that the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), the Leader of Opposition Business in the House, said that the Opposition will be watching to see how it works. Immediately, in a rare display of total unity, the Leader of the House (Mr Young) echoed the honourable member for Hume and said that the Government would also be watching. I can see nothing wrong with starting off the day with prayers, and then we have the new system whereby, instead of the presentation of individual petitions each day, they will be presented all together. I think that I am correct in saying that from now on honourable members will have to count the number of signatures. Will that happen?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—That will add authority and veracity to the petitions. If someone wants to come in here with three signatures on a petition-three people have the right to have their voices heard-the Clerk will stand up and say, for example, that a petition has been received from the honourable member for--
—Curtin.

—The honourable member for Curtin-asking that speeches be read-with only three signatures. Somebody might come in with a petition with 23,000 signatures. Only a few weeks ago, I presented a petition about the retention of the Australian flag with over 100,000 signatures. It came in in a quiet way and there was no differentiation under the present system between my example of the petition from the honourable member for Curtin with three signatures and the one from the 100,000 Queenslanders who want the retention of our flag.

SPEECH.PARA: We then suggested that we move into the committee and delegation reports. We have all watched with some horror in past years as reports are brought into the House at the end of a sitting and raced through, one each side. That has been a disgrace, and I congratulate the Government on being prepared to re-examine that procedure. Every week there will be private members' business, and that will be determined by a committee. We look forward to seeing how that works. At 12.30 every Thursday, if there are divisions, there will be divisions. This is the first time that the Australian Parliament has set a time of the day to hold divisions. That means that we are agreeing for the first time that divisions that may have been triggered off earlier in the morning will be held off until 12.30. That is really a breakthrough. We will see how this works. There may be other improvements in this field in the future.

Every Thursday there will be a grievance debate in which honourable members will be given the opportunity to raise the matters they normally raise in this debate. We then come to members' statements at 1.45 p.m. This particular proposal is not an accolade for the Government. We have had to drag the Government to it, almost by the collar. We all remember what happened immediately after we came back after the 1984 election. The Leader of the House, who is at the table, chopped that opportunity. The Australian Labor Party went to the polls believing that it would be re-elected with a 50- or 60-seat majority. It was returned with a majority of less than a dozen. The Minister realised how effective the Opposition had been in using notices of motion, so he wiped them completely. This side of the House was silenced. This proposal is a sop. To get this sop we have had to be prepared to have a quarter of an hour chopped from the adjournment debate each night. I believe, however, that the opportunity being provided for members to stand up and speak for 90 seconds is a move in the right direction. Such a provision has not crumbled democracy in Canada. The Canadian Parliament has withstood the introduction of this provision. The only thing that worries me is that the Minister has been so backward in coming forward in being prepared to agree to it. Any man or any woman who is a leader of the Parliament who is frightened of what Opposition members might say in 90 seconds must surely have something to hide. No wonder the Minister said before that he will be watching it.

With those few words I assure the Minister and the shadow Minister that this has not been the most invigorating and pleasant committee on which I have ever sat. That is no reflection on any of my colleagues on it. It is not an exciting task to examine the methods used by different parliaments around the world in the conduct of their business and try to draw out the best of those for our parliament. I sincerely hope that if the Government views this Committee as a way of keeping some honourable members in this Parliament busy it will inject a bit more excitement into it. However, we had a job to do. I believe that it has been done well. I often wish that the public could see that side of parliament when Australian Labor Party, Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia members sit together and work together in joint committees. For instance, Liberal and Labor members might join together against other Labor, Liberal and National Party members of the Committee or there may be different combinations. This is the time when members of parliament cease to be politicians with a colour on their backs and work together for the benefit of the cause or the committee on which they are sitting. I thank honourable members for this wonderful experience over the last three years. It is not one I would seek again. However, I am pleased to see that in some way I have been partly responsible for much needed changes in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by the good Minister, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and Leader of the House (Mr Young). I am very pleased that the Government has accepted the proposals put forward in this part of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. I am very much a new member to the Committee. However, I would like to place on record, even with my brief acquaintance, my appreciation of the hard work put into the Committee by the Chairman, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford). I also wish to place on record my appreciation, as a result of reading through the reports of the previous Committee, of the work put in by the membership and the Chairman, the then honourable member for Bowman, Mr Len Keogh. Without detracting from the contributions made by the current honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), I must say that I am sorry that my colleague, Len Keogh, is not still with us here.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very comprehensive committee report. It is one that I have no hesitation in agreeing with and supporting. The proposals contained in the report will give a greater role for what is described as `private members'. That is a quaint use of the word `private' because I understand that, in this sense, a private member is a member who is not the Speaker or a Minister. We want to be more public. Therefore, it is a quaint use of the word `private'. We want to be more public in our opportunities to speak on those matters which concern us most and those matters which we wish to put forward and initiate.

With the new Parliament House giving greater opportunities for the public to observe our work, our role will, indeed, be very public. I think it is very exhilarating to find that the time that will be made available to private members to be more public will be more than doubled. For example, there will be more opportunities to bring forward private members' Bills. I am one member of this House who has seconded a private member's Bill. I refer to the Bill debated in this House on 10 May 1973. It caused quite a stir at the time. It was called the Medical Practice Clarification Bill. It was often referred to as the law reform Bill or the McKenzie-Lamb Bill. I mention it, not because I want to remind honourable members about that time or the contents of the debate, but to recall the difficulties faced by the then Leader of the House, Fred Daly, who had to rearrange, reorganise and burrow into Government business time to have that Bill debated. The debate went on all day. It was quite a sacrifice for the Government of the day to push aside Government Business. I really cannot anticipate what private members' Bills will be put forward. However, I can say that it is a unique opportunity. It is an opportunity which we can extend even more to private members. I will be very interested to see the development in that area.

I take the point made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) in regard to the number of signatures on petitions. He said that by knowing the number of signatures in support of a petition we get a good measure of the public support. Currently, we cannot tell whether three signatures or 3,000 signatures have been appended to a particular petition. The only way that the public has of getting a message across in volume is perhaps to have only a few signatures on each petition but to keep presenting that petition time and time again to the Parliament. To present a petition with 1,000 signatures once is better than presenting a hundred petitions with 10 signatures on each which takes up the time of the Parliament. I think that having the number of petitioners recorded is a most worthy change to our Standing Orders.

I mention also that, although the Standing Orders provide that a Minister may respond to a petition, I would like to see a greater measure of obligation felt by Ministers to respond, at an appropriate time, to a petition should there be a fair measure of support for it. I support also the change to the grievance debate which will now be held not once a fortnight, or every two weeks of sitting, but weekly. As the Deputy Government Whip, I am conscious of the great scramble by private members trying to get an opportunity to speak on matters that are very important to them in the grievance debate. There is never enough time for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is when we can get them to come into the House.

—I inform the honourable member for Farrer that even if we doubled the number of opportunities to speak on the grievance debate it still would not be enough. I know very little about the success of the 90-second statements in the Canadian Parliament which was referred to by the Chairman of the Committee. He says that such a provision will be very popular. If I gauge correctly the success of a radio program in Canberra during which listeners have an opportunity to speak for one minute to get their message across, I think it will be very successful. In that one minute callers to the radio station have been able to get across quite comprehensively the particular points they want to make, without the trap that confronts us here of having to divide a speech into a beginning, a middle and an end-which is really another way of saying the same thing three times in a debate. There will be pressures on honourable member in that short time to be succinct, to the point and extremely relevant.
—Succinct, to the point of absurdity.

—The honourable member for Gippsland need not take part if he believes that it is absurd. I am sure that the vacancy he leaves will be taken up by other members on his side of the House. The decision to cut back the adjournment debate from 45 minutes to 30 minutes is perhaps a loss at first sight but, when we realise that there will be more opportunity on Thursdays, this is more than adequate. In particular, the adjournment debate is not broadcast. That is a pity. I am sorry that the Government has not supported the recommendation to broadcast adjournment debates. However, more broadcast time will now be available to private members to debate and present their particular opinions to the public. Even though the new Parliament House will be larger and accommodate more of the public, for every visitor to our galleries there are thousands of people on farms and in cars listening to the broadcast of Parliament. I agree with other members who say that when we go to the big House on the hill we will need to review our procedures. It is recognised that the work environment can dictate or condition our work practices as much as anything.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Banks said that it would be more of a people's house-I happen to have a few doubts about that-but will it be a member's House? There is some attraction in the current conditions here where we are forced because of lack of space to rub shoulders. There are far more opportunities to have casual conversation and to get a point across and discuss a matter briefly, whereas with the larger House-there is, more or less, an acreage of rooms over there, and a suite of rooms for members-there is every danger that we will be encapsulated in our own little domain and will rely on telephones rather than face to face conversations to discuss the matters of the House. Some intimacy will be lost at the new Parliament House. However, the change in environment will, perhaps, mean a change following our review of work practices.
I conclude by commending the co-operation shown by the Minister and the excellent work by the current Procedure Committee and the former Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure it is mildly anti-climactic to find all those innumerable hours and nights culminating here in what, by understandable time constraints, must be a fairly brief debate. On immediate reflection it stands to reason that the substantial report, having been furnished to the House some weeks ago and naturally inviting the attention of interested members, would be refined to the point where the views of members of the House, if it be not side by side, will be expressed through the executives and we will have a commonality of view which could produce a result here this evening. Hopefully that will prove to be the case, though I am intrigued as to how we will arrive at that happy state in respect of one notice of motion dealing with the reading of speeches. I will put that aside just for the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it is another tribute to the perspicacity of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) that we are not broadcasting this debate. I can just imagine those thoroughly mystified listeners trying to sort out the rites and practices of this place which, at times, seem to mystify and defy us as members; thus, we are sparing listeners the agony of trying to follow what we are on about. As the notices of motion cover about six pages of fine print in the Notice Paper, it stands to reason that there is not an opportunity to recapitulate, though the Chairman, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Mountford), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) and some other members of the Committee have embarked on a mild excursion to touch on some of those points.

It is not my intention to explore the ramifications; suffice to say that we have had an opportunity to address the matter. The House is very lightly populated, which is clear proof that this question will not be resolved as a consequence of the debate in this very tight time context. I mentioned earlier the question of the reading of speeches. This is the only matter which is designated for a free vote, to my understanding, and, therefore, it would perhaps be mischievous just to leave it hanging without a comment as to what may have motivated the Committee to make the recommendation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will do that later.
—I thought we were free to touch on these matters collectively, whilst not voting on it. I stand corrected.
—It is only the first three parts.

—Yes; I thought that in any event we were free to speak on them all but that we would put the questions separately. Nevertheless, I am quite amenable to that constraint, if that is the will of the House. I will just pass that by. I emphasise to the House that members of this ecumenical Committee, consisting of members of both sides, addressed themselves quite seriously to maximise the opportunities for members to be accorded their due whilst, at the same time, recognising that the government of the day had an urgent need to properly address substantial matters peculiar to the Government's responsibility and, therefore, their prospects of being able to address themselves on a regular, scheduled and a reliable basis should be a parallel consideration. I feel the Committee in the ultimate has produced a report and recommendations to the House, now manifest in the motions by the Leader of the House, which, I would like to think, vindicate the earnest endeavours of Committee members over a considerable period.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the new Parliament will prove to be a very substantial challenge and the Chairman's comments to the effect that the Procedure Committee's future address will be almost exclusive to this challenging environment in which we are about to move-the place on the hill. Contrary to general expectations, we are assured by those who have built the place that there is not a spot in that building from which members will not be able to access the chambers within the three-minute ringing of the bells presuming, of course, that they are not necessarily handicapped by having their attire in some temporary disarray. That is one point that we must ensure meets with the reasonable requirements of members in addressing themselves to the business for which they have come to this place.

I shall be interested to witness the outcome of these recommendations. They are not the end of the line, by any stretch of the imagination. In the meantime, I think it fully justifies the House's action in establishing the Procedure Committee and, in turn, the work that the Committee has put into its responsibility, admirably assisted by the Clerks, the Leader of the House and executive members of the Opposition. I think it augurs well for future address to these very important considerations that subscribe to the proper functioning of this Parliament, which is important to us all and to the people of Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEDURES FOR TABLING OF MINISTERIAL PAPERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:

That this House endorses in principle the recommendation of the Standing Committee on Procedure that the procedures for the tabling of ministerial papers following questions without notice, pursuant to standing order 101, be altered in accordance with the following arrangements:

(1) By 12 noon on each sitting day a schedule of papers to be presented will be made available to the Manager of Opposition Business and will be circulated to all Members in the Chamber at the first opportunity;

(3) Papers presented will continue to be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings, and

This Bill is the centrepiece of the Government's child support scheme. Many Australian families over the last 10 years have experienced the pain of marriage breakdown. That is something governments can do little to help-but government can take action to alleviate dramatic and sustained drops in living standards for children in those families. Poverty has for too long been the traumatic result of marriage breakdown for children in sole parent families. This Government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty. The child support scheme is central to achieving that objective.

This Bill will set up stage one of the scheme to ensure that parents who have the capacity to pay do not abandon the financial responsibility of supporting their children to the social security system. This Bill will make the legal right of children to be supported by both their parents a real right. We will turn what for most children is an empty promise into solid, regular financial support. Over half of the 800,000 Australian children in poverty are in sole parent families. Those families depend on pension and benefit and those payments are the only source of income for most of them-more than 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay regular maintenance for their children. This scheme will increase the number of families receiving maintenance, increase the level of that maintenance and will ensure that it is received on a regular basis.

The enforcement of child maintenance has been recognised as a significant social problem in major Western countries, such as the United States of America. While those countries have adopted various collection mechanisms, the problem has continued and they are now piloting the approach we are about to adopt in this country. We are in a unique position to be able to use our family law, taxation and social security powers under the Constitution to integrate a national system. In addition to the Child Support Bill 1987, it is necessary to enact two other pieces of legislation to give full effect to the first stage of this scheme.

My colleague the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) recently introduced into the Parliament the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 which will, when enacted, provide for child maintenance obligations to be given priority over all commitments of non-custodial parents, other than those necessary for their own support. That Bill will also put an end to the practice of maintenance being essentially nothing more than a top-up to social security benefits, by preventing the courts from considering social security eligibility when making orders that relate to maintenance. A further Bill, which I propose to bring before the Parliament early next year, will amend the Social Security Act 1947 to provide for changes to the way maintenance is treated in the social security system.

I turn now, Mr Deputy Speaker, to outline briefly the essential features of the Child Support Bill. Effective collection of maintenance has never been achieved in this country. The only way to ensure that children receive the support to which they are entitled is by a collection system that does not depend on voluntary payment. The deduction of maintenance automatically from salary or wages guarantees in the vast majority of cases that regular financial assistance is provided. The Bill will establish a Child Support Register which will record details of maintenance liabilities that will be enforceable under the Bill. There will be a Child Support Registrar who will be responsible for the administration of the Bill and the keeping of the Child Support Register. Under the Bill, the Child Support Registrar will be the Commissioner of Taxation. The Registrar will administer the Bill through a section of the Australian Taxation Office to be known as the Child Support Agency. A Child Support Agency within the Australian Taxation Office is best equipped to perform this task for three reasons: the Tax Office has an existing relationship with employers, who under the scheme of the Bill will be required to deduct maintenance from the salary or wages of liable employees; the Tax Office can best trace those persons who seek to avoid their obligations under the Bill; and the Tax Office has substantial experience in the enforcement of financial obligations.

The Bill is drafted in such a way that all child maintenance liabilities that are payable on a periodic basis under a court order or a registered maintenance agreement are registrable on the Child Support Register. In my statement on 24 March this year, I outlined the parameters that would be applied to limit the population to be covered by the scheme.

The Child Support Agency will collect periodic child maintenance that relates to children of parents who separate after the commencement of this Bill, or-where the parents have not cohabitated-to children born after that day. In all cases where the person receiving the maintenance is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit, the Child Support Agency will be able to collect the maintenance. The Child Support Agency will take over the functions of State collection agencies. It will collect any orders lodged with those agencies on the date their functions are taken over. It is proposed to establish these parameters by regulation so that if in the future there are sufficient resources to extend the scope of the scheme it will not be necessary to amend the Bill.

A significant feature of the Bill is that in the vast majority of cases maintenance will be deducted automatically from the salary or wages of liable parents. The effect of this automatic withholding is that regular payments are assured to custodial parents. The Government rejects the suggestion that automatic withholding be imposed only when default in payment occurs. Overseas experience is that a default will almost certainly occur in the two years after an order for payment is made. Stigma attaches to automatic withholding if it is imposed upon default and this would detract from the success of the scheme. The enforcement of child support has been recognised as a problem in the United States since the mid-1970s. Those States that have adopted less effective collection mechanisms to overcome this have found that the problem has continued and are now moving to the approach we have adopted. In some cases it will simply not be possible to impose automatic withholding and in these cases the liable parent will be required to pay the maintenance directly to the child support agency.

The Bill also provides a statutory mechanism which ensures the payment to custodial parents of moneys paid over to the child support agency. The Bill contains strict secrecy provisions for Commonwealth officers and for employers regarding any information obtained through their involvement in the scheme. The Bill provides comprehensive appeal and objection rights to all parties affected by the registration of a maintenance liability coverered by the Bill. Since my announcement of 24 March this year the Government has decided to extend the scheme to cover spousal maintenance where that maintenance is payable in conjunction with registrable child maintenance. In addition spousal maintenance will also be collectable by the Child Support Agency in respect of individuals who are 45 years of age or over and in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit. Spousal maintenance will also be collectable where the order or agreement has been lodged for collection with a State collection agency and the Child Support Agency takes over those functions.

The revenue effect of all these measures was estimated for 1987-88 Budget purposes to be net gains of $7.6m in 1987-88 increasing to $192.8m in 1989-90. Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would mention that the Government intends to improve on this first stage of the child support scheme with the introduction as soon as is practicable of a system of formula assessment of maintenance obligations. Effective collection of maintenance is only part of the problem. Levels of child support awarded by the courts or agreed upon by parents have been consistently inadequate when compared to the real cost of raising children. The provisions of the Family Law Amendment Bill giving child support a priority over all commitments of the parents, other than those necessary for their own support, will in part redress this problem. The Child Support Consultative Group, under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Fogarty of the Family Court of Australia, will be advising the Government on elements of that formula early next year. The child support scheme is a major initiative of this Government of which Australians can be proud. It may be the forerunner for other countries to examine in addressing the real problem of child poverty. I commend that Bill to honourable members. In doing so, I present the explanatory memorandum on this Bill, further copies of which will be available tomorrow.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend various taxation laws to give effect to a range of policy decisions of the Government. The more important amendments to be made relate to provisions of the income tax law. They include measures to encourage the development of off-shore banking in Australia through a withholding tax exemption for interest paid to non-residents by off-shore banking units. Capital gains tax roll-over relief is being given for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts. Amendments to correct certain deficiencies in the taxation of lump sum superannuation and similar payments are also proposed.

The Bill will remove special concessional treatment for expenditure on buildings for scientific research or other research or development purposes and on the development of certain computer software. Other amendments include further concessions to permit shelf companies to satisfy `common ownership' tests contained in the income tax law, modifications to thin capitalisation provisions and measures to extend the coverage of the income tax law to a range of activities in off-shore areas and external territories. A number of technical amendments will correct anomalies and deficiencies in the taxation laws. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will now further outline the more significant measures contained in the Bill.
Off-shore Banking Units

This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision announced on 1 July 1986 and expanded on 9 April 1987, to provide an interest withholding tax exemption to facilitate off-shore banking in Australia, primarily for dealings in foreign currencies with non-residents. Exemption will be confined to banks that are subject to the Banking Act, State banks and other financial institutions authorised to deal in foreign exchange which are gazetted by the Treasurer to be off-shore banking units. An off-shore banking unit may be a separate department of a bank or other financial institution, keeping separate accounts, or a separately incorporated body. The Bill will exempt from interest withholding tax interest and amounts in the nature of interest paid by off-shore banking units on specified borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986.

The scheme of the legislation allows an off-shore banking unit to borrow or accept deposits of foreign currency funds either overseas or on the domestic market or of Australian currency from non-residents. It is basically intended that they deal with these funds only in three ways: by on-lending them to non-residents, depositing them with another off-shore banking unit, or in purchasing foreign securities.

To preserve Australia's withholding tax base, and in recognition of the practicalities of tracing and monitoring the application of particular borrowings, any misapplications of funds that attract the concession provided are to bear a special income tax at a penal rate. This tax will be declared and imposed by an associated Bill, about which I will speak shortly. Consistent with the basic concept of separate dealings by off-shore banking units in foreign currency transactions, any foreign income tax losses incurred by off-shore banking units from off-shore banking business may be offset only against subsequent profits from that business. There will be similar quarantining of off-shore banking income for foreign tax credit purposes, precluding the transfer of excess foreign tax credits within a company group of which the off-shore banking unit is a member. This measure is estimated to have a direct revenue cost of $2m annually, which may be offset by higher company tax collections on off-shore banking business profits.
Capital Gains Roll-over Relief

Effect is being given to the proposal announced on 29 September 1987 to extend roll-over relief-that is, deferral of liability-from tax on capital gains for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts. Roll-over relief will be given where a resident company is interposed between a unit trust and its unitholders who dispose of their units to the company in exchange solely for non-redeemable shares in the company. Such a reorganisation will qualify for the relief where it is entered into, or commenced, after today. The reorganisation must be carried out by a direct exchange of units for shares or by redemption or cancellation of the units and separate issue of the shares. The interposed company will be required to elect that the roll-over provisions apply and declare that eligibility conditions have been met. Unitholders will separately elect for roll-over. They will thereby be able to choose, for capital gains tax purposes, between having their units treated as disposed of at the time of the reorganisation or to defer any capital gains liability until they later dispose of the exchange shares. Shares received in exchange for units acquired before 20 September 1985 will also be taken to have been acquired before that date.

For the company, an effect of its election may be to have an appropriate proportion of the units taken as having been acquired before 20 September 1985 and therefore not subject to the capital gains and capital losses provisions on a later disposal-the proportion to be determined by reference to the net value of assets of the unit trust that were acquired before that date.

For the remainder of units taken to have been acquired on or after 20 September 1985, cost bases will be determined by reference to the cost bases of the assets of the unit trust that were acquired on or after that date reduced by any liabilities of the trust attributable to those assets. The nature of this proposal is such that a reliable estimation of the potential revenue effect cannot be made.
Eligible Termination Payments

The Bill also contains measures, announced on 12 January 1987, that will amend the law relating to the taxation of lump sum superannuation and kindred payments. The amendments remedy shortcomings in the law that have been exploited so as to defeat the Government's objectives in the retirement incomes area. First, the Bill will ensure that a lump sum payment made after 12 January 1987 on the death of a superannuation fund member will be taxed as an eligible termination payment if the payment is made as an alternative to a superannuation pension or annuity. This is consistent with a policy of discouraging the conversion of retirement incomes into tax free lump sums, and will overcome arrangements by which some superannuation funds dress up as tax free lump sums payments that are in substance a commutation of a pension or annuity.

The Bill will also close a loophole that allowed persons who are not dependants to receive superannuation and other termination payments tax free on the death of a taxpayer. Death benefits paid after 12 January 1987 will be exempt from tax only if paid to dependants. A range of measures is being introduced to ensure that annuities purchased with rolled-over eligible termination payments do not qualify for tax concessions unless they provide genuine retirement incomes for the taxpayer and the taxpayer's dependants. The concessions are the deferment of tax on the eligible termination payment and tax exemption for the income derived by the annuity issuer from that business.

The first of the new requirements is that the annuity contract must provide for the annuity to commence to be payable by the annuitant's sixty-fifth birthday. Another measure will limit the class of persons who may be nominated under a roll-over annuity contract to receive residual benefits on the purchaser's death. It will exclude adult children who are not financially dependent on the purchaser. By a further amendment, only the spouse of a deceased annuitant will be allowed to roll over an eligible termination payment received as the residual capital value or commutation of a roll-over annuity.

The other rules being introduced for roll-over annuities are aimed at securing timely release of an annuitant's income entitlements once age 65 is reached. Those rules are in two groups. One will set upper limits on any capital payments permitted under the contract on termination of the annuity after age 65. Under the other group of rules, the Commissioner of Taxation will look to whether the annuity contract permits unreasonable deferral of any annuity income payable after 65. Together, the rules reflect a policy that tax exemption for issuers of roll-over annuities cannot be justified beyond the normal retirement age if the tax payable on the relevant annuity income continues to be deferred.

The Bill sets out matters that the Commissioner will have regard to in applying the rules. For example, the guaranteed component of an annuity and any bonus, or supplementary, component are required to be considered separately and according to different principles. More detailed explanations can be found in the explanatory memorandum.

Another amendment will exempt from the eligible termination payment taxing provisions the residual capital value of a deferred roll-over annuity paid to a dependant on the death of the purchaser during the deferment period. This will bring the tax treatment of those payments into line with payments to dependants of deceased superannuation fund members and approved deposit fund depositors. The various amendments affecting roll-over annuities are to apply to annuities purchased after 12 January 1987, the date of announcement of the measures.

As a complementary measure, immediate annuities not purchased wholly with rolled over eligible termination payments are to be required to satisfy conditions similar to those for roll-over annuities if the earnings of annuity issuers from that business are to be tax free. The conditions are to apply from the time of purchase, rather than at age 65 and apply to relevant annuities purchased after today.

A further measure will treat de facto spouses on the same basis as legal spouses for the purposes of the lump sum payments taxing provisions. The Bill will also clarify two matters: firstly, that a roll-over payment to a personal or self-employed person's superannuation fund does not qualify as a tax deductible contribution to the fund; and secondly, that an annuity is regarded for these purposes as being presently payable-and therefore, an immediate annuity-at all times after the commencement of the first payment period. This package of measures is expected to result in a net revenue gain of $4m in 1986-87 and $30m in a full year.
Research and Development Activities

The Bill implements two changes announced on 20 November 1987 to the concessions for expenditure on scientific research and other qualifying research and development activities. The three-year write off for expenditure on the construction or acquisition of buildings used exclusively in these activities will be removed, except where the taxpayers who incur the expenditure had committed themselves to the construction or acquisition before 21 November 1987. This change will ensure more efficient use of the revenue available for research and development activities by focusing upon more productive, and innovative, investments.

The second change is an anti-avoidance measure to deny deductibility as `Research and Development Activities' for expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987 on the development of computer software not intended for multiple application by persons not associated with the developer. Other changes arising from the Government's review of the research and development tax concession, which were also announced on 20 November 1987, are proposed to be introduced in the autumn sittings next year. The changes included in the Bill under this heading are estimated to save $5m in a full year.
Shelf Companies

The Bill includes measures complementary to those introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987 to permit a newly incorporated company, commonly referred to as a shelf company, to be eligible for various company grouping provisions of the income tax law. One change will backdate shelf company eligibility to the income year in which each of the relevant grouping provisions was first made available. Another change will extend the operation of the grouping concessions to shelf companies acquired by the mechanism of issuing new shares and redeeming the subscriber shares in the shelf company.
Other Matters

The remaining measures contained in the Bill are not matters of major significance and I shall not take up the time of the house by dwelling on them. Detailed explanations are set out in the explanatory memorandum. For immediate purposes I note that they deal with the following subjects. First, some technical redefinition of off-shore areas is being made, the main change being to amend Australia's taxing rights over certain sea installations used for tourism, recreation, business or transport activities.

Unintended consequences of the imputation system legislation are being remedied so that non-resident life assurance companies are freed of dividend withholding tax on any unfranked dividend income attributable to superannuation and certain life assurance policies derived through their Australian branches on or after 1 July 1987. More generous transitional rules are being given to some companies with substituted accounting periods to enable them to rearrange their debt-equity ratios to comply with the thin capitalisation measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987.

The income tax rebate for taxable bonuses received under short term life assurance policies is being extended under an agreement with the Western Australian Government to policies issued by the State Government Insurance Corporation of that State.

Finally, a minor technical amendment is being made to the quarterly provisional tax system's legislation; a redundant machinery provision is being removed from the sales tax law; and full effect is being given to the abolition of stamp duty and tax on transfers of debentures in the Australian Capital Territory. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

This Bill will formally declare and impose an income tax, the liability for which may arise under one of the measures contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987, about which I have just spoken. That liability may arise in respect of certain dealings by banks and other financial institutions which are declared to be off-shore banking units in accordance with provisions being inserted in the Income Tax Assessment Act by that Bill. Liability for an income tax, at a penal rate, could apply if an off-shore banking unit misapplies borrowings that qualify for the withholding tax exemption, for example, by on-lending to residents of Australia. The income tax is to be based on a formula contained in the relevant provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The tax is a sanction against the use of the funds that have been exempted from withholding tax otherwise than, broadly, for off-shore banking business, but may be subject to remission in appropriate circumstances. This Bill imposes that income tax and declares the rate of the tax to be 300 per cent of the formula amount. I commend the Bill to the House.

(6) If recipients are not required to satisfy Australian authorities at regular intervals that they are living at the given address, what are the formalities to cancel welfare payment upon the death of the recipient.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During the year ended 30 June 1987, $117,555,000 was paid to pensioners living permanently overseas.

(2) Statistics of the amounts paid in each country have not been collected. Each annual report of the Department of Social Security provides details of the number of pensions paid overseas by country of residence.

(3) Automatic payment of pension is conditional on a pensioner remaining eligible for a pension. Pensioners are required to notify changes in their circumstances which will affect their eligibility. The eligibility of all pensioners is reviewed regularly.
(5) Yes. Entitlement review forms include a question about the pensioner's current residential address.

(6) Pensioners are required to keep the Department informed of their residential addresses. Cheques are posted 4 weekly to their residential addresses. Review Forms are also forwarded to their residential addresses annually. Checks are made to ensure that the form is returned by the pensioner.

When information is received that a pensioner has died, payment is stopped. Payments made after the date of death are recovered. When there is a surviving pensioner spouse, the rate of pension payable to the spouse is reassessed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Schools Commission and Participation and Equity Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Commonwealth Schools Commission continue in its present form.

(2) Is the Government committed to a new program to replace the Participation and Equity Program in post-primary schools; if so, (a) when will it be introduced, (b) what will be its funding allocation and (c) how will it be implemented and administered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government has accepted in principle a model for a new set of portfolio advisory arrangements which have been developed by the Halton Task Force. The Government is currently undertaking an extensive range of consultations prior to announcing the membership, role and functions of the Councils to operate under the proposed National Board of Employment, Education and Training.

(2) No. The Participation and Equity Program has been guaranteed funding until the end of 1987 but it is not possible in the current economic climate to provide funds for any new programs. Through the stimulus given by the Participation and Equity Program there is now a large measure of self-sustaining momentum in school systems and schools in this area. The significant real per capita increases flowing to schools under the General Recurrent Grants Program and the priority areas identified for the use of these extra funds will increase this momentum.
